50.description: Transcript of 'This Week' interview with Vice President Joe Biden
50.text:
In an interview with Jake Tapper on "This Week," Vice President Joe Biden defended the Obama administration's policies on Wall Street reform, healthcare legislation, and stimulus, arguing that substantial progress has been made despite public skepticism.

Biden acknowledged that the public may not fully understand the contents of these legislative packages, but argued that they are crucial for addressing the problems inherited by the administration. He highlighted the importance of consumer protections in the Wall Street reform bill and cited historical examples of regulation in other industries.

Regarding healthcare reform, Biden explained that misinformation spread by the insurance industry has contributed to public skepticism. He emphasized the positive aspects of the bill, such as tax cuts for small businesses and protections for individuals with preexisting conditions.

Biden expressed confidence in the upcoming midterm elections, stating that the administration will be vindicated for its policies. He acknowledged that public opinion may not favor the administration at the moment, but he believed that as people become more informed, they will recognize the positive impacts of these policies.

In discussing the economy, Biden addressed concerns about the slow recovery and the lack of job growth. He attributed these challenges to the economic recession inherited from the Bush administration and external factors such as the collapse of the European economy. He argued that the administration's policies have laid the foundation for job creation and economic stability.

Tapper also asked Biden about the controversy surrounding General Stanley McChrystal's remarks about the administration. Biden stated that he did not take the comments personally and believed that McChrystal's removal was necessary. He expressed confidence in General David Petraeus and the counterinsurgency policy in Afghanistan.

The interview also touched on other topics, such as Iraq, Sudan, and the fight against Islamic terrorism. Biden discussed the progress in Iraq and the upcoming referendum in Southern Sudan, emphasizing the need for credible elections to ensure stability in the region. He highlighted the administration's strategy of engaging with moderate Muslim countries and stabilizing governments in areas susceptible to radicalization.

Overall, Biden defended the administration's policies and expressed confidence in their ability to address the challenges facing the country.
50.title: Biden discusses Wall Street Reform, Healthcare Legislation, and Stimulus in Interview

51.text:
In a speech delivered in the Rose Garden at 11:00 A.M. EDT, President [Name] placed pressure on Congress to make a choice between supporting big oil companies or standing up for the American people.

Highlighting the record profits being made by oil companies and the rising prices at the gas pump, the President criticized the billions of dollars in taxpayer subsidies received by the industry each year. He argued that it was unfair to burden American taxpayers with additional costs while these companies enjoyed massive profits.

The President also emphasized that the oil industry was thriving and didn't need further financial assistance. He cited the fact that the three biggest U.S. oil companies collectively earned over $80 billion in profits last year, with Exxon alone pocketing nearly $4.7 million every hour. He also mentioned that increased oil prices only resulted in higher profits for these companies.

Addressing the argument in favor of subsidies, the President noted that the oil industry already pays lower tax rates than most other industries due to the billions they receive in tax giveaways. He questioned why those who dismiss investments in clean energy technologies were fighting so hard to maintain these subsidies.

The President expressed a belief that America's energy strategy should include drilling for oil, but it should also prioritize investments in clean energy technologies such as wind power, solar power, and biofuels. He called for using subsidy money to double-down on these investments, emphasizing the need to break the cycle of high gas prices and reduce dependence on other countries for oil.

Highlighting that the United States only has 2 percent of the world's known oil reserves while consuming over 20 percent of the global oil supply, the President argued that increasing domestic oil production wouldn't solve the long-term energy challenge. He stressed that controlling America's own energy destiny required diversifying energy sources and reducing reliance on foreign markets.

The President concluded his speech by reiterating his commitment to an all-of-the-above energy strategy and his belief in American ingenuity and imagination. He called on Congress to vote against oil subsidies and invest in the future, emphasizing that the American people were watching and seeking faith in their representatives.

The President's remarks reflect a continuing debate regarding the role of government subsidies in the oil and gas industry and the need to prioritize clean energy investments for the future.
51.title: President Urges Congress to End Oil and Gas Subsidies

52.description: Secretary of homeland security on protecting the nation on Memorial Day Weekend
52.title:
Sec. John Kelly on Manchester investigation, keeping America safe
Content: This is a rush transcript from "Fox News Sunday," May 28, 2017. This copy may not be in its final form and may be updated.

CHRIS WALLACE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: I’m Chris Wallace.

Keeping America safe after the terror attack in England. What steps is the government taking this Memorial Day weekend?

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOHN KELLY, HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: It's a constant threat and we always have to be vigilant.

WALLACE: We’ll discuss the investigation into the bombing and the response here in the U.S. with the secretary of homeland security, General John Kelly, live, only on "Fox News Sunday."

Then, new reports the president's son-in-law Jared Kushner discussed setting up a secret communications channel between the Trump transitions in the Kremlin. We’ll ask our Sunday panel where this takes the expanding probe into Russian interference.

Plus, President Trump returns from his first trip overseas to a domestic agenda in trouble, from ObamaCare repeal and replace to the budget, some on Capitol Hill wonder whether Congress will pass anything.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-SOUTH CAROLINA: Yes, definitely dead on arrival.

SEN. DICK DURBIN, D-ILLINOIS: This is step backwards. You’re not going to make America great again with this budget.

WALLACE: We’ll break down the president's priorities and prospects with a number two Democrat in the Senate, Dick Durbin, and Republican senator, Dr. Bill Cassidy.

And our power player of the week flying high for the Blue Angels.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Boy, is it sweet when we put all that together and get that synergy and you feel that fuzz.

WALLACE: All, right now, on "Fox News Sunday."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WALLACE: And hello again on this Memorial Day weekend from Fox News in Washington.

President Trump is back at the White House arriving late last night after a largely successful nine-day trip to the Middle East and Europe. But he returns to a spreading scandal about links between the Kremlin and some of his current and former advisors, and to a domestic agenda that stalled in Congress.

We’ll get to all of that this hour, but we begin with terror, that suicide bombing at a concert in Manchester, England, that killed 22, just the first of four savage attacks this week around the world.

Joining us now, the man in charge of keeping America safe, the secretary of homeland security, General John Kelly.

Mr. Secretary, welcome to "Fox News Sunday."

Before we get to terror, let me ask you about the hot story in Washington now. These revelations about Jared Kushner trying to set up a back channel to the Kremlin, through the Soviet and -- the Russian ambassador. Your reaction to that? Is there anything improper with that?

KELLY: Well, I don't know if it's true or not. I know it’s being -- it's being reported in the press.

WALLACE: It has been confirmed to me the conversation took place.

KELLY: OK. Then I would just tell you, Chris, that I think any channel of communications back or otherwise with a country like Russia is a good thing. I mean, multiple ways to communicate back and forth is a good thing with a country I think, and particularly a country that’s like Russia. So, it doesn’t -- it doesn't bother me.

I mean, you just have to assume, obviously, that what you’re getting is -- may or may not be true, they may be working you. But that's the whole point. I mean, that communication goes into the White House as a data point in terms of discussion. So, I don't see the big deal.

WALLACE: Let me -- you say you don't see a big deal?

KELLY: No, I think any time you have channels of communication with a country, particularly one like Russia, I wouldn’t criticize it.

WALLACE: But you talked about a data point into the White House. This is during the transition.

KELLY: Right.

WALLACE: These were private officials.

KELLY: Right.

WALLACE: We have one president at a time. Does that make a difference?

KELLY: You know, I mean, obviously, during the transition period, the people in transition, the incoming Trump administration is not in a position to do anything to inhibit with the Obama administration literally days before they transitioned out. So, again, as they begin to build relationships, there's nothing wrong with that. As they begin to build their own situational awareness with Russia in this case, I don't see an issue here.

WALLACE: OK. Let's turn to your day job. What's the latest on the Manchester bombing? Have they rolled up the network that was supporting the bombers, and what have you learned from this plot that will help you better protect the U.S. homeland?

KELLY: I mean, I don't know what the -- actually the better way to put it, I can't comment on whether they finish their investigations, or roll -- you know, completed rolling up on the network that we’re dealing with. But I would just say that this is -- yes, I’ve said it many times, it really is a generational struggle. This is one tragedy in line with dozens of other tragedies in the world.

I mean, last week, you had Manchester, you had Egypt, you had Indonesia, you had the Philippines, all ISIS-inspired or ISIS-controlled terrorist attack.

WALLACE: Was there something different about this network and the way this was pulled off that says to you, gee, we've got to up our game?

KELLY: Well, it’s this kind of -- in my view, there's kind of three types of terrorist attacks. The most sophisticated that we look at, that is against aviation, that's the hardest to do but it's the biggest payoff for these people.

Then you have kind of the middle of the road one, which I think this one was. It’s a network. It's hard to do. You have to construct a bomb and all, and then you have kind of the low-end where -- I mean, just as tragic but you have people running people over in trucks, that kind of thing.

But this is just the way terrorism is today and I think it will be around for many, many years to come. You know, the good news is those officials in the United Kingdom, Europe, around the world are relentless. They are just as relentless in terms of trying to prevent these things as the terrorists aren't trying to create them.

The good news is, for our country, we have not had an outside the United States terrorist attacks since 9/11. And that goes to the issue of those that fight our away game, that’s DOD, NSA, CIA, and those that fight the home game. That’s DHS, FBI, local law enforcement.

WALLACE: Let me pick up on this, because part of the story this week was the leak of information about the bomber and the bombing that made its way into the U.S. media, and that set off this exchange.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

THERESA MAY, BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: I made clear to President Trump that the intelligence that is shared between our law enforcement agencies must remain secure.

REX TILLERSON, SECRETARY OF STATE: We take full responsibility for that. And we, obviously, regret that that happened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: How was this kind of sensitive information leaked to "The New York Times"? And, General, why is it that whether it's politics or terror, our intelligence agencies, our law enforcement agencies, can't keep a secret?

KELLY: It's outrageous. When I call -- immediately after the attack, I called my counterpart in U.K., offered my condolences. By the way, the third time I’ve offered her, Amber Rudd, my condolences in 120 days. That's how frequent this kind of -- these terrorist attacks are happening.

Anyways, she rightfully and very graciously accepted the condolences and leaned into me on this leak. It's outrageous. I don't know why people do it. It jeopardizes not only investigations, it puts people's lives in jeopardy.

I don't why people do it, but they do. And that's the world we live in.

WALLACE: Let's get to what you're going to try to do to protect the homeland. There are a lot of crowded events in the summer, concerts, sporting events. How do you harden these soft targets like this concert? And do you have new thoughts because this person didn't get into the event, he was outside the event, what do you do about parameters?

KELLY: We -- one of the great things about America, there's many great things but we are a free and open society. And in many -- and I wouldn't change that at all. But that's also one of our vulnerabilities. People can live their lives day in and day out, privacy issues, all of that, it's a good thing. It’s what America is all about. But as I say, that is a vulnerability.

The good news is to all Americans, I mean, the good news is that local state law enforcement today -- not to even go down the issue of the FBI, DHS -- it's in their DNA now to harden. We are just about as hard as we can be. I don't know if there's a way to prevent these kinds of things in the kind of society we live in.

WALLACE: Let me pick up on that, because I want to play a clip of your testimony before Congress this week. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLY: It's everywhere, and that’s -- you know, that's the nature of this threat that we are dealing with. As horrible as Manchester was, my expectation is we’re going to see a lot more of that kind of attack.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: A lot more of that kind of attack, here in the U.S.?

KELLY: I think we’re relatively -- we have no specific -- we have threats all the time, but no, right now, specific threat. But that goes to the fact that we are over here and not over there.

The fact is that it's the caliphate is being destroyed, that is Syria and Iraq, there are large numbers of returning fighters, Western Europe, and, you know, in many cases like this guy that did this thing in Manchester, he’s a citizen of the U.K. In this case, he’s a passport holder. I don't if the U.K. had any idea that he was outside -- that he was in Libya, but I think he’s also traveled to other points.

The point is, they have a real threat and it's growing, it’s metastasized, as fighters come back from the caliphate to be I believe to be more of this kind of thing.

The good news is all decent people, all decent governments, and it doesn't matter whether we are politically close to them or not, all governments for the most part are sharing tremendous amounts of information, passport-type information, aviation, travel information. But, you know, people like this are below the radar.

WALLACE: I want to pick up on aviation because you are in the process of making some big decisions on aviation. And I want to do a lightning round, quick questions, quick answers.

Are you going to ban laptops from the cabin on all international flights both into and out of the U.S.?

KELLY: I might. That's a quick answer.

WALLACE: Yes, well, expand a little bit.

KELLY: Well, there’s a real threat. Numerous threats against aviation, that's really the thing that they are obsessed with, the terrorists, the idea of knocking down an airplane in flight, particularly if it’s a U.S. carrier, particularly if it's full of mostly U.S. folks, people. It's real. You know that I implemented I think on the 21st of March a restriction on large electronic devices in the cabins from ten points of origin.

WALLACE: Right.

But there was talk, as you say, about all international flights both into and out of the U.S. When you say you might, when are you going to make that decision and what’s that going to do to the screening lines?

KELLY: (INAUDIBLE) follow the intelligence. The very, very good news is that we are working incredibly close with friends and partners around the world. We're going to, and in the process of defining this, but we are going to raise the bar for generally speaking aviation security much higher than it is now.

So -- and there’s new technologies down the road, not too far down the road that we will rely on. But it is a real sophisticated threat and I will reserve that decision until we see where it's going.

WALLACE: Another lightning round question, I do need a quick answer here because we’re running of time. The TSA is testing tighter screening of carry-ons, and the idea that people who bring their carry-ons are going to have to unpack them and put food in one bin, and electronics in the another bin, and paper in another bin.

Are you going to spread that nationwide and what’s that going to do to the screening lines?

KELLY: Yes, I mean, the reason we’ve done, TSA, of course, works for me. The reason we've done that is because of -- people trying to avoid the $25 or $50 or whatever it is to check a bag are now stuffing your carry-on bags to the point of, you know -- well, they can't get any more in there. So, the more you stuff in there, the less the TSA professionals that are looking at what's in those bags through the monitors, they can't tell what's in the bags anymore. So, if you put --

WALLACE: So, are you going to do that nationwide?

KELLY: We might, and likely will.

WALLACE: Soon?

KELLY: Well, what we’re doing now is working out the tactics, techniques and procedures, if you will, in a few airports to find out exactly how to do that with the least amount of inconvenience to the traveler.

WALLACE: A couple final questions I want to ask about the travel ban. The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a ruling this week continuing the stay on President Trump's revised travel ban -- and I want to put up -- the chief judge called it, the revised travel ban: an executive order that in text speaks with vague words of national security, but in context drips with religious intolerance, animus and discrimination.

Mr. Secretary, judge after judge has said that this is a Muslim man that violates the Constitution.

KELLY: They are dead wrong.

WALLACE: Well, I mean, you say that, but they are the ones who were --

KELLY: They are wrong. Remember the seven, now six countries? These were the same countries identified by the Obama administration that we should be extra cautious about and backed up, you know, by the United States Congress. That's where those seven countries came from.

The fact is that in those countries, we have very little ability to actually verify, vet the people that are coming out of those countries. So, what the president and it's not a travel ban, remember. It’s the travel pause. What the president said, for 90 days, we were going to pause in terms of people from those countries coming to the United States that would give me time to look at additional vetting to see --

WALLACE: OK. I want to pick up on that and why you’re even talking about the travel ban, because I want to put some numbers on. Take a look at this.

The first executive order that was issued on January 27th banned citizens from seven nations from entering the U.S. for 90 days, suspended the refugee program for 120 days, as you say, a pause, while you set up an extreme vetting program. It's now been 121 days since that first order. So why don't you have the program in place?

KELLY: We are actually implementing it. The irony here is, had it stood, we would have had the 90 days to study. We’re not even studying what would be procedures, because we are enjoined and can't do that. In the meantime --

WALLACE: You can't study extreme vetting?

KELLY: No. We’re -- the irony again is we can't study it, but I’m just guessing, and implementing.

But we are going to find implement ways to determine who this -- an individual is, and remember, most of these countries have no passports. They have no police. They have no intelligence. Many of the countries in question don't even have a U.S. embassy there to help us vet. The U.N. will tell you it's almost impossible to vet these people from these countries because there are no passports and all the rest of it.

We have to figure out a way to determine who they are and why they come into the United States. Otherwise, we’re guessing. And this president, John Kelly doesn't want to guess when it comes to national security and protection of the U.S. population.

WALLACE: Secretary Kelly, thank you. Thanks for sharing part of your holiday weekend with us.

KELLY: Absolutely. Thanks.

WALLACE: Up next, new reports that Jared Kushner attempted to set up a back channel between Russia and the Trump transition. We’ll bring in our Sunday group to discuss the expanding Russia probe.

Plus, what would you like to ask the panel about the continuous leaks in Washington? Just go to Facebook or Twitter @FoxNewsSunday, and we may use your question on the air.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, D-FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We were furious about the past presidential election of a man whose presidency would eventually end in disgrace with his impeachment for obstruction of justice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: Hillary Clinton talking about Richard Nixon in her commencement speech at Wellesley College, but clearly taking a shot at President Trump. By the way, Nixon resigned before he was actually impeached.

And it's time now for our Sunday group: the head of Heritage Action for America, Michael Needham, Charles Lane of The Washington Post, Gerald Seib from The Wall Street Journal, and National Security Council staffer, Gillian Turner.

And just to catch you up, President Trump returns home to reports that his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, met with the Russian ambassador to the U.S., Sergey Kislyak, in December, and that they discussed setting up a secret secure channel between the Trump transition and the Kremlin. That communications link reportedly to be based in a Russian diplomatic facility in Russia.

A source close to the Trump administration tells me the conversation did take place but he says it was the ambassador who proposed the back channel, not Kushner, so the Russian military could talk with Trump advisors about the situation in Syria and the source points out that the secure link was never set up.

So, with that as a preface, Gerry, your reaction to the Kushner story, and how does this complicate the already complicated investigation of links between the Kremlin and the Trump transition?

GERALD F. SEIB, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well, look, I mean, back channels are not unusual, they are not unprecedented. This one might have seemed perfectly innocent. Two problems though with it. One is, this happened during the transition, it seems to violate as you suggested earlier in the show the only one president at a time rule. And the second one is it’s Russia, after a campaign in which the Russian connection to the campaign, the Russian interference in the campaign was a big issue.

And I think the fact that it was at a time when people were looking for whether there were going to be signs of special favors for Russia as a result of help they might have given President Trump, then-President-elect Trump during the campaign, that's what makes this a big story, is the context of the conversation as much as the actual content.

WALLACE: Michael, I want to ask you, one, whether it's a big story, and, secondly, about the talk we are hearing, that is just rampant in Washington today about major changes in the White House that they’re going to set up a rapid response operation to deal with all the incoming leaks, that the president has hired at least one criminal defense lawyer and may be process of hiring a team and the staff is urging the president to let the lawyers vet his tweets. I mean, it really does sound like they’re going on a war footing on this.

MICHAEL NEEDHAM, CEO, HERITAGE ACTION FOR AMERICA: Yes, I don't know if it's a major story, there are several investigations going on. They probably should be allowed to work their course. It's kind of exhausting reading some of these new stories and trying to figure out what did you read three weeks ago that’s just being recycled, versus what new?

I think it's smart for the administration to try to put this stuff to the side, have, you know, a team that looks at these issues, and another team that looks at a lot of real policy issues, which are closer to the American people. You have the most conservative, exciting budget that's come out in a decade.

WALLACE: We’re going to get to the agenda in the next segment.

(CROSSTALK)

WALLACE: I mean, at the very least, it seems dumb.

NEEDHAM: Clearly, the optics of these are awful, and I think that especially when you have people who are new to the political system coming in and getting advice from a guy in Mike Flynn who probably didn't show the best judgment through a lot of this, you know, dumb might be a good word for it. I don’t know. You know, I think Kushner said a couple of weeks ago that he was happy to participate with the Senate investigation. He said he’s happy to participate with this investigation.

You are at a disadvantage when you are the focus of an investigation and your lawyers are saying, don't participate, don't comment, and everyone else in the country seems more than eager to talk about it. So, I think a little prudence in keeping our mouth shut while we let the investigations play out is probably fair and we’ll see what comes up in them.

WALLACE: You talk about the fact that they're all the stories and sometimes it's hard to remember what you've heard this week and what you heard last week. And this gets to the question of leaks. I asked our staff to put together, let's put it up on the screen, a list of the headlines from just the last two weeks. This is just Sunday two weeks ago until today. And as you can see, there's been a torrent of disclosures from intelligence and law enforcement officials.

Gillian, as somebody who worked in the government, have you ever seen anything like this? And, you know, the conservatives talk about a deep state, that there are people embedded in law enforcement and embedded in the intelligence community that are trying to bring this president down. It sure seems like it's true.

GILLIAN TURNER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL: So, to me on the question of leaks, it seems that without a doubt leaks of information today are the number one threat to U.S. national security interest across the globe. And I think for evidence of that, we need look no further than the very public reprimand, we the United States had to endure from Britain earlier this week, in the wake of the Manchester attacks. A reminder that the British-U.S. intelligence cooperation, relationship, is one of the closest that has ever existed. And in my lifetime, in government and policy, I have not seen something so public, so public a risk (ph)

(CROSSTALK)

WALLACE: Most of these leaks aren’t about national security. They are about Trump's political security.

TURNER: Yes. And so, this gets to the question of the deep state. So, I’m somebody who likes to push back against the narrative having been a civil servant in the government. Again, in the national security community is different than the political community, the rest of the policy community. But I will say that from I have seen and experienced, it does not exist.

There is not this liberal --

WALLACE: How do you define this?

TURNER: There isn’t a liberal core of people -- put it this way, for a hard fact, more than 50 percent of the federal workforce today is made up of people that joined the government prior to President Bush's tenure in office. So, the idea that these are Obama holdovers is simply not true, it's not the case.

I think that when we talk about why individuals leak information, the explanations are as varied as human beings’ psychology. So, for example, a lot of things we are seeing leaked about the president are probably being leaked by his senior staff to hurt one another. That's not unique to the Trump administration.

WALLACE: We ask you for questions for the panel and we got some different reactions in this question of leaks.

Adri Ane sent us on Facebook: Do whistleblowers hold a vital role in the health of a democracy holding those in power to accountability?

But chuck Coo had a different take: Simple question. If our intelligence agencies are as good as advertised, why can't they find the leakers?

Chuck, how do you answer both of them about leaks?

CHARLES LANE, THE WASHINGTON POST: Well, as a member of the press, and is a believer in the role of the media and holding government accountable, I’m not going to come out against leaks, because, you know, for all the leaks that may cause this or that official trouble, there's going to be another one that does play an important role in accountability.

But going back to what Gillian said, I think part of the reason that these leaks are flowing so uncontrollably to the viewer’s question is the factional struggle within this administration. You know, we have this famous dispute between Bannon and Kushner that supposedly was papered over. But I wouldn't be surprised if, you know, those were present two currents, to put it politely, within the White House that are trying to get bad stories out about one another.

And this goes to your point about the staff shakeup and so on and so forth. You can shake up the staff all you want, but if man at the top is not laying out a clear and consistent line, is not himself modeling behavior, for example, by not blowing an Israeli source in a meeting with a foreign government, that sets the tone that this stuff is not really on, then it will continue.

NEEDHAM: I take your point about the responsibility of the press and how leaks play into as it requires a responsible press also. That when James Fallows of The Atlantic today put side-by-side The Washington Post in The New York Times and how they treat, I think it was three unnamed sources in the White House talking about Jared Kushner and his desire to be here and stay here, this is not an urgent story. This is not something that’s getting out there.

I don't think you see in the press, The Times and The Washington Post, the way they are playing this kind of using leakers to try to unearth the truth and taking two months like

(CROSSTALK)

WALLACE: We need to --

NEEDHAM: It’s kind of getting ridiculous.

WALLACE: We need to -- because we’re going to run out of time. Let me simply say, we're just receiving information. It’s people who had sworn, oftentimes taken legal oaths not to divulge the information, they are the ones putting it out. We’re just the recipients.

All right. We have to take a break here. We’ll see you a little later.

When we come back, Senators Dick Durbin and Bill Cassidy. Is the president's agenda, both his new budget and the new effort to repeal and replace ObamaCare in trouble?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WALLACE: Coming up, President Trump releases his budget.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My administration is laying a foundation to build a future of economic prosperity and achieve American greatness.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: But does it have any chance of getting through Congress?

Two key senators join us next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WALLACE: A look outside the beltway of the Indianapolis Motor speedway, home to this weekend's Indianapolis 500.

Back from his first foreign trip, President Trump's focus will now shift to his domestic agenda, his new budget and a bill to repeal and replace ObamaCare.

Joining us to discuss the president's priorities from Springfield, Illinois, the Senate’s number two Democrat, Dick Durbin. And here in Washington, Louisiana senator and doctor, Bill Cassidy, who’s on both the Senate Finance and Health Committees.

Well, senators, before we get to the Trump agenda, I’ve got to ask you about the big story in Washington. This weekend, the Jared Kushner story, discussions about setting up a possible back channel with Russia.

Senator Durbin, what's wrong with that?

DURBIN: The bottom line, of course, is we now have a special counsel in Bob Mueller. I have the highest level of confidence in him. And I hope that he will follow all the evidence, all the leads, and all the suggestions. And I’m sure he will.

WALLACE: Do you have any specific comment about the Kushner conversation and whether or je should keep his security clearance?

DURBIN: Well, of course not. I mean this is a rumor at this point and whether it is something that should be followed up on, I’ll trust Bob Mueller's judgment.

WALLACE: Senator Cassidy, are you troubled by this?

CASSIDY: I agree with Dick’s assessment. And I’ll say, when you speak to folks back home, voters across the nation, they’re more concerned about their climbing health care premiums and the need to have jobs with better wages and better benefits. This will play out. We will know eventually. Right now Americans need help with their premiums.

WALLACE: Well, you know what then gentlemen, let's switch to health care. And the Congressional Budget Office, non-partisan, released its score of the House bill this week. And let's put the numbers up on the screen. It would reduce the deficit $119 billion over ten years, but 23 million more people would be uninsured by 2026. The cost of insurance, according to the CBO, for a 64-year-old earning $27,000 a year would increase from $1,700 a year under ObamaCare to more than $13,000 under the GOP bill. Here's what Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said this week.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-NY, MINORITY LEADER: Unless you’re a healthy millionaire, Trumpcare is a nightmare. This report ought to be the final nail in the coffin of the Republican effort to sabotage our health care system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WALLACE: Senator Cassidy, is Schumer right?

CASSIDY: So the Senate will write its own bill. And it shouldn't be the final coffin because right now there's families sitting around their kitchen table, they’re play $20,000, $30,000 and $40,000 a year for premiums and there's about to be a 40 percent increase in many states in these premiums. Cassidy-Collins, a bill I’ve introduced with Susan Collins, we have four co-sponsors.

WALLACE: Yes, we’re going to get into that in a --

CASSIDY: But that said, actually would -- would -- would meet that family’s needs and I think it should be a place we go and those families are asking us to address those issues.

WALLACE: So -- so what would you say to Americans? How should they regard the House bill?

CASSIDY: The House product, the Senate will have its own product. We will go to conference. But I think the Senate product, I'm hopeful, will be more likely to address their needs.

WALLACE: Senator Durbin, I know what you’re going to say, and the CBO certainly indicates there are problem with repeal and replace, but ObamaCare has its own problems. You heard Senator Cassidy mentioned some of them. Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City just announced this week that it has lost $100 million through 2016 and that it is going to pull out of exchanges. That means that in 25 counties in western Missouri they may have no insurer at all. Doesn’t something have to be done dramatically?

DURBIN: Well, it should be. But first we ought to have an administration that supports our health care system. What the Trump administration has done since day one is to find ways to cut off support for our current health care system, lack of advertising, for example, to bring new people on board so we have larger insurance pools and lower premiums. We have to have an effort made to sustain the current system while we repair it. We shouldn’t be sabotaging it.

WALLACE: Wait, wait, wait, wait, senator --

DURBIN: But let’s look at the bottom line here. What the Republicans --

WALLACE: Senator Durbin, let me just point out, when Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City says they’ve lost $100 million in 2016, you can't blame that on Trump. He wasn't president.

DURBIN: No, of course it is not a situation where the system we have is perfect, and it isn't. I voted for it. And it needs to be repaired. And I think Bill Cassidy and Susan Collins are at least willing to sit down in a constructive fashion and deal with that. Bill and I have had conversations about that. I'm sorry. 54.text:
In a recent Medium post, Hillary Clinton, a Democratic presidential candidate, made a significant claim regarding gun violence and its impact on minority youth. According to Clinton, gun violence surpasses the next nine causes of death combined for young African-American men.

To verify the accuracy of this statement, we delved into the data available on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website. Through the CDC's search form, we obtained information on the ten most common causes of death for African-American males aged 15 to 24 in 2014.

When considering gun-related homicides alone, the data revealed 2,256 deaths in this category, compared to 2,119 deaths in the subsequent nine leading causes combined. Therefore, Clinton's statement holds true based on these figures.

Moreover, if we include accidents and suicides involving guns, the gap widens even further. In total, there were 2,533 gun-related deaths across all ten categories, contrasted with 2,002 deaths caused by other factors.

However, it is essential to note that the accuracy of Clinton's statement relies on the chosen age range. Specifically, for African-American boys aged 10 to 14, the statement does not hold true. In 2014, there were 38 gun-related homicides, 10 gun suicides, and three unintentional injuries caused by guns, amounting to a total of 51 deaths. Conversely, for that age and racial group, the top ten causes of death accounted for 271 deaths unrelated to firearms, such as diseases.

Nonetheless, considering Clinton's use of the age range of 15 to 24 for defining "young," it appears to be a reasonable choice.

In conclusion, based on data from the CDC, Hillary Clinton's statement that "Gun violence is by far the leading cause of death for young African-American men, outstripping the next nine causes of death combined" is accurate within the defined age range of 15 to 24. Therefore, we rate her statement as True.
54.title: Hillary Clinton's Statement on Gun Violence as a Leading Cause of Death for Young Black Men

55.description: The following is the prepared text of President Obama’s speech to Congress on the need to overhaul health care, as released by the White House.
55.text:
In a highly anticipated speech to Congress, former President Barack Obama laid out his vision for a comprehensive health care plan that aims to improve the lives of millions of Americans. Titled "Making Health Insurance Work for You," the plan seeks to address several critical issues faced by individuals and businesses alike.

Under this proposed plan, insurance companies would no longer be able to deny coverage based on pre-existing conditions, a significant concern for many Americans. Additionally, the bill, once signed into law, would prohibit insurance companies from terminating coverage when individuals fall sick or reducing coverage when it is needed most. The implementation of arbitrary caps on coverage amounts, both yearly and throughout a lifetime, would also be deemed unlawful.

Recognizing the burden of out-of-pocket expenses, the plan seeks to establish limits on the amount individuals can be charged, ensuring that no American goes bankrupt due to medical bills. Furthermore, routine check-ups and preventive care, such as mammograms and colonoscopies, would be covered by insurance companies at no additional cost. The objective is to detect diseases like breast and colon cancer at an early stage, effectively saving lives and reducing healthcare costs.

For the tens of millions of Americans currently without health insurance, the second part of the plan promises to offer quality, affordable choices. The proposal introduces a new insurance exchange – a marketplace where individuals and small businesses can compare and purchase health insurance at competitive prices. Insurance companies would be incentivized to participate in this exchange to cater to millions of potential customers. This approach aims to mirror the affordable insurance options enjoyed by large companies and government employees.

To ensure accessibility for those unable to afford the lower-priced insurance available through the exchange, tax credits will be provided based on individual needs. Moreover, all insurance companies seeking access to this new marketplace must abide by consumer protection regulations.

However, disregarding the availability of affordable options, there may still be individuals, particularly the young and healthy, who choose to forgo coverage. Likewise, there may be companies that refuse to provide their workers with health care benefits. This irresponsibility has a financial cost for the rest of society. The burden often falls on taxpayers when uninsured individuals require expensive emergency room visits, and it puts businesses providing adequate healthcare at a disadvantage compared to their competitors.

Obama urged everyone to do their part, emphasizing that widespread participation is crucial for successful implementation of the proposed insurance reforms. Without a collective effort, crucial elements such as the coverage of pre-existing conditions would be unachievable.

The former president concluded by pressing on the importance of embracing affordable options for all Americans, emphasizing that access to proper healthcare should not be a luxury but a fundamental right. With this comprehensive plan, he aimed to provide greater security, stability, and opportunity for millions of Americans.
55.title: Obama's Health Care Speech to Congress

56.description: Obama ends up in middle of an unlikely controversy — the debate over Miss California’s position on gay marriage.
56.text:
During a press conference addressing the controversy surrounding Carrie Prejean's disputed title in the Miss USA competition, pageant owner Donald Trump expressed his support for Prejean's views on gay marriage, comparing them to those of former President Barack Obama.

According to Trump, Prejean's response on the subject during the pageant mirrored that of Obama. "It's the same answer that the president of the United States gave," Trump stated. "She gave an honorable answer. She gave an answer from her heart."

Shortly after Trump's comments, Prejean herself reiterated his statement while addressing reporters. She emphasized that her views on marriage were shared not only by Obama but also by the sitting secretary of state and many other Americans. 

During the final round of the Miss USA pageant, Prejean was asked by judge Perez Hilton about her stance on same-sex marriage. Her response was as follows: "I think in my country, in my family, I believe that a marriage should be between a man and a woman. No offense to anybody out there, but that's how I was raised."

Prejean's remarks have sparked intense debate and garnered considerable attention from both supporters and critics. While some applaud her for expressing her personal beliefs, others argue that her answer contradicts the principle of inclusivity and equality that the Miss USA competition stands for.

It is worth noting that Barack Obama himself, during his presidency, openly expressed his opposition to same-sex marriage in 2008. However, he later changed his stance and became a vocal advocate for marriage equality, ultimately supporting the legalization of same-sex marriage nationwide in 2015.

As the controversy surrounding Prejean's remarks continues to unfold, it highlights the complex and deeply divisive nature of the ongoing debate on gay marriage in the United States.
56.title: Trump and Prejean Echo Similar Stance on Gay Marriage, Citing Obama's View

57.text:
Just before Mitt Romney left the Massachusetts governor’s office in 2006, 11 of his top aides purchased their state-issued computer hard drives, and the Romney administration’s e-mails were all wiped from a server, according to records obtained by the Globe. 

Secretary of State William F. Galvin, responsible for overseeing the state Public Records Law, said it was odd that state property, such as hard drives, was being sold to private individuals. He emphasized that public officials have an obligation to preserve their records, whether in electronic or paper form. 

Galvin also clarified that while the Public Records Law does not explicitly include the governor, e-mails should still be preserved and turned over to the state archivist. The Supreme Judicial Court ruling in 1997 specified that e-mails don't have to be released to the public, but they need to be preserved.

Mark Reilly, Chief Legal Counsel for Governor Deval Patrick, explained that the current administration has no electronic record of any Romney administration e-mails. He stated that computers used during that period were replaced and the server was taken out of service, with all files removed from it.

Mark Nielsen, Romney’s former chief legal counsel, defended the actions of the governor’s office, stating that employees were given the option to purchase old equipment upon leaving. Nielsen stated that the purchases were in accordance with the law and longstanding executive branch practice. 

While it appears that Romney administration officials did not violate the letter of the state Public Records Law, Pam Wilmot, executive director of Common Cause Massachusetts, believes they may have gone against its spirit. She expressed concern that information generated during the administration belongs to the people of the Commonwealth and it seems that the deletion of all records may be a loss for the state.

Although Patrick’s office does not have electronic records of the Romney administration's e-mails, there are approximately 700 to 800 boxes of paper records from that era at the state archives in Boston.

This incident raises parallels to a controversy involving Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston in 2009, when one of his aides deleted almost all of his e-mails from the previous five years. The act was not considered a crime, as the aide was not willfully attempting to hide the correspondence.

In conclusion, the actions taken by Mitt Romney's staff to eliminate e-mail records and allow aides to purchase computer hard drives upon leaving office have raised concerns about the preservation of public records and transparency in the state government. The debate over the letter versus the spirit of the law continues, with critics arguing that the deletion of records may have resulted in a loss of valuable information.
57.title: Before leaving governor’s office in 2006, Mitt Romney’s staff eliminated e-mail records

58.description: Doctors Ezekiel Emanuel and Rep. John Fleming square off over Obamacare and how it impacts doctors....
58.text:
When it comes to healthcare, the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of heated debate and controversy. With its aim to provide affordable and accessible healthcare to all Americans, the law has brought significant changes to the doctor-patient relationship. In this article, we will explore how Obamacare has affected you and your doctor.

Under Obamacare, one of the biggest changes is the emphasis on preventive care. Insurance plans are now required to cover certain preventive services, such as vaccinations and screenings, without cost-sharing. This means that as a patient, you have access to a wider range of preventive services, which can help detect potential health issues early on.

Additionally, Obamacare has expanded access to healthcare through the Medicaid program. Previously, eligibility for Medicaid was limited to certain low-income individuals and specific categories such as children, pregnant women, and the elderly. However, the expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act extended coverage to millions of low-income adults who were previously uninsured.

For many Americans, the introduction of health insurance marketplaces, also known as exchanges, has been a game-changer. These online platforms allow individuals and small businesses to compare different insurance plans and choose the one that best suits their needs and budget. Moreover, individuals who cannot afford insurance may qualify for subsidies or tax credits to help offset the cost of coverage.

The doctor-patient relationship has also undergone changes under Obamacare. With the law's focus on quality of care, doctors are encouraged to incorporate preventive measures and evidence-based practices into their treatment plans. There has been a shift towards a more collaborative approach to healthcare, with patients actively participating in decisions regarding their treatment and care.

Furthermore, electronic health records (EHRs) have become an integral part of healthcare under Obamacare. The law promotes the use of EHRs to improve coordination and continuity of care. By having access to a patient's complete medical history, doctors can make more informed decisions and provide personalized care.

However, it is important to acknowledge that the implementation of Obamacare has not been without its challenges. Some individuals have faced difficulties in finding doctors who accept their insurance plans, leading to concerns about limited provider networks. Additionally, there have been debates regarding the affordability of insurance premiums and the overall sustainability of the healthcare system.

As we continue to navigate the complex landscape of healthcare under Obamacare, it is crucial to assess both its successes and shortcomings. While the law has undoubtedly expanded access to care and placed a greater emphasis on preventive services, there are areas that still require attention and improvement.

In conclusion, the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, has brought significant changes to the doctor-patient relationship and the overall healthcare system. Through its focus on preventive care, expanded access to Medicaid, introduction of health insurance marketplaces, and emphasis on quality and collaboration in healthcare, Obamacare aims to provide affordable and accessible care for all Americans. Yet, challenges remain and continued efforts are needed to ensure the effectiveness and sustainability of these reforms.
58.title: Rebooting: You and your doctor under Obamacare

59.text: This article is a summary and paraphrasing of Senator Bernie Sanders' prepared remarks on Democratic Socialism in the United States from November 19, 2015. The content has been reorganized for clarity and conciseness.
59.title:
In his inaugural remarks in January 1937, in the midst of the Great Depression, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt looked out at the nation and saw the dire circumstances faced by its citizens. He witnessed families struggling to make ends meet, individuals lacking access to education and basic necessities, and poverty running rampant. In response to these hardships, Roosevelt implemented various programs that put people back to work, alleviated poverty, and restored faith in the government. Many of these programs, such as Social Security and the minimum wage, were labeled as socialist at the time. However, they have since become integral components of the American welfare system and contributed to the growth of the middle class.

Fast forward to 2015, and while the United States is better off economically, there are still millions of families struggling to survive and make ends meet. The middle class has dwindled over the past four decades, and faith in the political system is at an all-time low. A small portion of the population continues to amass vast amounts of wealth, while the majority struggle to keep up.

Senator Bernie Sanders believes that it is time for a change. He argues that the United States needs a political movement that challenges the ruling elite and fights for the rights and needs of working families. Democratic socialism, as Sanders defines it, aims to create an economy that benefits everyone, not just the wealthy. It calls for a political system that works for all Americans, not just a select few. Sanders believes in a government that guarantees economic security for all citizens, where everyone has access to healthcare, education, and a decent standard of living. He advocates for policies such as a $15 minimum wage, Medicare for all, tuition-free public colleges, and reforms to combat income inequality and campaign finance corruption.

Sanders emphasizes the importance of a vibrant democracy where every citizen has the right to vote and participate in the political process. He criticizes the low voter turnout in the United States and the corrupt campaign finance system that allows wealthy individuals and corporations to exert undue influence. Sanders proposes overturning the landmark Citizens United decision and implementing public funding of elections.

Furthermore, Sanders highlights the need for a strong coalition, including Muslim nations and countries like Russia, to combat the global threat of terrorism. He calls for a collective effort to destroy ISIS, with Muslim nations leading the fight and receiving support from the United States and other major powers. Sanders also urges countries in the region, such as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and Qatar, to take more responsibility in the fight against terrorism.

In conclusion, Senator Bernie Sanders believes that democratic socialism is the way forward for the United States. He envisions an America where economic security is a right, everyone has access to affordable healthcare and education, and the political system is free from corruption. Sanders advocates for a coalition of nations to combat terrorism and emphasizes the need for greater involvement from Muslim countries in the fight against ISIS. Overall, he aims to create a society that works for all Americans, not just a privileged few.

60.description: This document summarizes the comprehensive 2010 health reform law, often called the Affordable Care Act or ACA, including changes made to it by subsequent legislation, with a focus on provisions to…
60.text:
The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, also known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA) or Obamacare, is a comprehensive healthcare reform law that was enacted in 2010. The goal of the ACA is to increase access to affordable health insurance coverage for all Americans and to improve the quality and affordability of healthcare.

One of the main provisions of the ACA is the requirement for most U.S. citizens and legal residents to have health insurance. This individual mandate aims to expand coverage by ensuring that more people have insurance. Those who do not have coverage are subject to a tax penalty, which increases over time.

To help individuals and families purchase coverage, state-based American Health Benefit Exchanges were created. These exchanges provide a marketplace where individuals can compare and purchase health insurance plans. Premium and cost-sharing credits are available to individuals and families with incomes between 133-400% of the federal poverty level.

The ACA also includes requirements for employers. Larger employers with 50 or more full-time employees are required to offer health insurance to their employees or face penalties. Smaller employers with fewer than 50 employees are exempt from this requirement.

Medicaid, the government program that provides health coverage for low-income individuals, was expanded under the ACA. The eligibility for Medicaid was increased to 133% of the federal poverty level, allowing more individuals to qualify for the program.

The ACA also introduced premium and cost-sharing subsidies to help individuals and families afford health insurance. These subsidies are available to U.S. citizens and legal immigrants who meet income limits. The amount of the subsidy is based on a sliding scale, with lower-income individuals receiving higher subsidies.

In addition to these provisions, the ACA includes various tax changes related to health insurance and financing health reform. These changes include taxes on individuals without coverage, increased taxes on certain healthcare-related items, and tax credits for small businesses that provide health insurance to their employees.

The ACA also created health insurance exchanges, called American Health Benefit Exchanges, where individuals and small businesses can purchase qualified health coverage. These exchanges are administered by either a governmental agency or a non-profit organization.

The ACA established an essential health benefits package that provides a comprehensive set of services and covers at least 60% of the actuarial value of the covered benefits. The package is defined and updated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

Overall, the Affordable Care Act aims to improve access to healthcare coverage, reduce healthcare costs, and enhance the quality of healthcare for all Americans. While it has faced ongoing debates and challenges, it remains a significant piece of legislation with a profound impact on the healthcare system in the United States.
60.title: Summary of the Affordable Care Act

61.description: A new TV ad from the McCain campaign portrays the Arizona senator as a leader in the fight against global warming. The a
61.text:
TV ad from the McCain campaign portrays the Arizona senator as a leader in the fight against global warming.

The ad begins with fast-paced music and horns honking, creating a sense of urgency. It showcases black-and-white scenes of crowded freeways, smokestacks belching, and a glacier collapsing to symbolize the dire consequences of climate change.

"John McCain stood up to the president and sounded the alarm on global warming . . . five years ago," the narrator says.

The stark black-and-white scenes transition into more pleasant color footage of a wind turbine against a bright blue sky and water flowing through a dam, representing renewable energy and environmental solutions.

"Today, he has a realistic plan that will curb greenhouse gas emissions. A plan that will help grow our economy and protect our environment."

The ad includes visuals like a newspaper headline stating "McCain climate views clash with GOP," highlighting McCain's independent stance on climate change.

Indeed, records from the Congressional Record confirm that McCain spoke up about global warming in January 2003. Even before that, as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, he held hearings on the issue.

On Jan. 9, 2003, McCain and Sen. Joe Lieberman introduced the Lieberman-McCain Climate Stewardship Act, a bill aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by implementing caps and allowing trading of emission rights.

When introducing the bill, McCain emphasized its significance as the "first comprehensive piece of legislation" to tackle emission caps.

"The U.S. is responsible for 25 percent of worldwide greenhouse gas emissions," he said. "It is time for the U.S. government to do its part to address this global problem, and legislation on mandatory reductions is the form of leadership that is required."

In contrast, the Bush administration preferred voluntary efforts rather than cap-and-trade programs to address climate change.

Manik Roy, director of congressional affairs for the Pew Center on Global Climate Change, confirmed that McCain had been working on the climate change bill since 2001, but its progress was disrupted by the 9/11 attacks. Although the Lieberman-McCain bill ultimately failed in October 2003, receiving a 43-55 vote, Roy highlighted its significance in raising awareness and shaping the Senate's understanding of government action on global warming.

"It is absolutely correct that McCain stood up on this issue, forcing the Senate to focus on it when nobody else thought it made sense, and he did it with strong opposition from the White House," Roy said.

He praised McCain as "a huge leader on this issue in the Senate."

Based on the evidence presented, it can be concluded that McCain's statement on his early involvement in addressing climate change is true.
61.title: McCain Spoke Up Early

62.description: It's not often you see someone stand up and say, "Tax me more!" Yet that's just what famed investor Warren Buffett has d
62.text:
It's not often you see someone stand up and say, "Tax me more!"

Yet that's just what famed investor Warren Buffett has done in an op-ed in the New York Times headlined, "Stop Coddling the Super-Rich." Buffett says that very wealthy people like himself pay lower tax rates than the middle class, thanks to special tax categories for investment income.

"While the poor and middle class fight for us in Afghanistan, and while most Americans struggle to make ends meet, we mega-rich continue to get our extraordinary tax breaks," he writes.

As an example, Buffett said he paid an effective tax rate of 17.4 percent, while people who worked in his office made much less but paid higher effective tax rates of between 33 percent and 41 percent, averaging 36 percent.

"If you make money with money, as some of my super-rich friends do, your percentage may be a bit lower than mine. But if you earn money from a job, your percentage will surely exceed mine — most likely by a lot," Buffett wrote. "To understand why, you need to examine the sources of government revenue. Last year about 80 percent of these revenues came from personal income taxes and payroll taxes. The mega-rich pay income taxes at a rate of 15 percent on most of their earnings but pay practically nothing in payroll taxes. It’s a different story for the middle class: typically, they fall into the 15 and 25 percent income tax brackets and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot."

Buffett's op-ed inspired a reader to write to us and ask how Buffett's numbers could be correct. As our previous fact-checks have shown, about half of all Americans pay no federal income taxes because they are low income. And when you analyze who pays the bulk of federal income taxes, it's people with higher incomes. So we decided to fact-check Buffett's statement that "the mega-rich pay income taxes at a rate of 15 percent on most of their earnings but pay practically nothing in payroll taxes... (The middle class) fall into the 15 percent and 25 percent income tax brackets, and then are hit with heavy payroll taxes to boot."

Before we get to the heart of the fact-check, it's best if we review a few basics of the tax code that Buffett's op-ed takes for granted. This review proves the point that the federal tax code is extremely complicated, so bear with us.
62.title: Warren Buffett: Super-rich Pay Lower Tax Rates Than Others

63.description: Defense Secretary Robert Gates will consider sending some 3,000 Marines to Afghanistan to thwart any spring offensive by Taliban militants, the Pentagon said on Wednesday.
63.text:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Defense Secretary Robert Gates is considering deploying an additional 3,000 Marines to Afghanistan in order to counter any potential spring offensive by Taliban militants, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday.

According to Pentagon press secretary Geoff Morrell, this proposal is currently under consideration by Secretary Gates. "He will review it thoroughly before providing his approval," Morrell stated.

Over the past two years, violence in Afghanistan has escalated, with the Taliban engaging in a guerilla war in the south and east, alongside high-profile suicide and car bombings across the country.

In an effort to address the escalating violence, Gates has been urging NATO allies to contribute more troops to Afghanistan. However, if the Secretary of Defense endorses this proposal, it will indicate that Washington has acknowledged the need to provide a significant proportion of additional combat forces.

To respond to the increased violence, Gates had previously ordered a surge in U.S. forces in early 2007, resulting in a record-high of 27,000 troops currently stationed in Afghanistan. Approximately half of these troops are part of the 40,000-strong NATO security assistance force, while the rest are involved in various missions, including counter-terrorism and training Afghan troops.

While NATO claims to have thwarted last year's attempted Taliban spring offensive, overall violence has risen by 27 percent compared to the previous year. The southern province of Helmand has experienced a staggering 60 percent increase in violence, as reported by the U.S. military last month.

Geoff Morrell stated that the majority of the additional Marines would be deployed to southern Afghanistan, where British, Canadian, and Dutch troops have been heavily engaged in combat. "The aim is to have them in place by April to prevent a repeat of last spring's attempted comeback by the Taliban," Morrell explained. "This deployment is a one-time, seven-month mission."

Following his meeting with allies in Scotland last month, Secretary Gates hinted at a shift away from pressing NATO nations to contribute combat troops, given the political challenges they face. He suggested that allies should focus on supporting other aspects of the mission, such as rebuilding Afghanistan. This change in approach places a greater burden on the United States in terms of combat responsibilities.

"The commander on the ground requires additional forces, and since our allies are unable to provide them, we are now considering shouldering some of that additional load," Morrell added.

The Taliban government was ousted by U.S.-led forces in late 2001 in response to the September 11 attacks on the United States.

Morrell mentioned that the plan to deploy the Marines would be included in a schedule of deployment proposals to be presented to Secretary Gates on Friday.

The plan involves sending a Marine Air Ground Task Force to combat the Taliban in southern Afghanistan, along with deploying a Marine battalion to train Afghan forces.

According to a U.S. military official, the Joint Staff of the Pentagon developed this plan in response to a request from Admiral William Fallon, the top U.S. commander for the Middle East. The proposal also enjoys the support of Admiral Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
63.title: U.S. Considers Sending 3,000 More Troops to Afghanistan

64.description: Biographical sketch of New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani traces his rise to City Hall from his childhood in East Flatbush, Brooklyn; notes that he was born on May 28, 1944, grandson of Italian immigrants, and was Federal prosecutor; photos (M)
64.text:
Rudolph William Giuliani, the 107th Mayor of the City of New York, has embarked on a confident journey from his early accomplishments as a class president, editor on the law review, and a bold young prosecutor to becoming Gotham's beloved and action-oriented mayor. With an impressive track record that includes being the No. 3 man at the Justice Department, a crime-fighting United States Attorney, and an archenemy of the Mafia, Giuliani's rise to prominence has been nothing short of extraordinary.

Now at the helm of City Hall, Giuliani, 53, has become an omnipresent figure in New York City. Whether rushing from a burned-out building to a subway derailment or standing by the bedside of a wounded police officer, he has positioned himself as Gotham's reliable take-charge guy. One could easily view him as the city's own superhero.

Undoubtedly, Giuliani's leadership has had an undeniable impact on the city. Even his adversaries begrudgingly acknowledge his effectiveness. New York City, once deemed ungovernable, is now responsive to discipline, with crime rates plummeting and the feeling of safety noticeably increasing for both residents and tourists alike.

However, amidst his numerous accomplishments, one cannot help but notice Giuliani's temperament. He appears to hold firm in his belief of mayoral infallibility, seemingly convinced of his righteousness as long as he holds the position. The mayor's reactions can be severe when his actions or decisions are questioned, often regarding any opposition as an attack on his character. This perception has earned him a reputation for being mercurial, leaving little room for dissenting opinions.

While Giuliani's confidence has undoubtedly contributed to his success, it is important to acknowledge the need for open dialogue and constructive criticism within any leadership role. A leader who welcomes differing viewpoints can foster growth and innovation, ultimately benefiting the community they serve.

As New York City's mayoral race continues to unfold, it will be intriguing to observe the impact of Giuliani's temperament on his campaign. Can his confident journey withstand scrutiny and appeals for alternative approaches, or will his unwavering self-assuredness become a potential liability? Only time will tell.
64.title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Republican Candidate; A Mercurial Mayor's Confident Journey

65.text:
The Nobel Peace Prize, one of the most prestigious international awards, has been awarded a total of 103 times to 140 Nobel laureates since its inception in 1901 up until 2022. This includes 110 individuals and 30 organizations who have been recognized for their remarkable contributions to peace and diplomacy.

Among the recipients, three-time awardee, the International Committee of the Red Cross, was honored in 1917, 1944, and 1963 for their dedication to providing humanitarian aid in conflict zones. Similarly, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has been awarded twice, in 1954 and 1981, for their efforts in protecting refugees and displaced persons.

In total, there are 27 individual organizations that have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, each making significant contributions to the promotion of peace and democracy.

The laureates for the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize were Ales Bialiatski, a human rights advocate from Belarus, along with the Russian human rights organization Memorial and the Ukrainian human rights organization Center for Civil Liberties. These laureates have demonstrated their commitment to civil society, advocating for the right to criticize those in power and protect the fundamental rights of citizens. They have worked tirelessly to document war crimes, human rights abuses, and the abuse of power.

Another notable recipient was Maria Ressa and Dmitry Andreyevich Muratov in 2021. They were awarded the prize for their efforts to safeguard freedom of expression, a crucial element for democracy and lasting peace.

The World Food Programme (WFP) was awarded the Peace Prize in 2020 for its relentless efforts to combat hunger, improve living conditions in conflict-affected areas, and prevent starvation from being used as a weapon of war.

Previous laureates include Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed Ali, recognized in 2019 for his efforts to achieve peace and international cooperation, particularly through his initiative to resolve the border conflict with neighboring Eritrea. In 2018, the Prize was awarded jointly to Denis Mukwege and Nadia Murad for their tireless work to end sexual violence as a weapon of war and armed conflict.

The Nobel Peace Prize has also been awarded to institutions that have made significant contributions to global peace. The European Union (EU) received the prize in 2012 for its relentless pursuit of peace, reconciliation, democracy, and human rights in Europe.

These examples illustrate the diverse range of contributions that have been recognized by the Nobel Peace Prize. From advocacy for human rights, disarmament, and democracy to humanitarian and diplomatic efforts, the prize serves as a testament to the importance of civil society and the pursuit of peace worldwide.

The recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for 2023 is yet to be announced. The announcement is scheduled for Friday, October 6th at 11:00 CEST.

For further information and a complete list of Nobel Peace Prize laureates, please visit the official Nobel Prize website.
65.title: Nobel Peace Prize has been awarded 103 times to 140 laureates between 1901 and 2022

66.description: This data snapshot provides the latest data on Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) enrollment and policy trends nationally and across the states through June 2011, based on survey resp…
66.text:
The latest data on Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) enrollment and policy trends have been released, shedding light on the state of CHIP nationally and across the states as of June 2011. The comprehensive report, based on survey responses and data provided by CHIP directors in all 50 states and the District of Columbia, reveals some noteworthy findings.

According to the report, the total number of children enrolled in CHIP reached 5.3 million in June 2011. This signifies an increase of 178,000 children from June 2010, reflecting a growth rate of 3.5 percent. Interestingly, this rate of growth is similar to the prior annual period (3.3 percent), indicating a stabilization in enrollment growth since the onset of the recession.

While the number of children accessing CHIP continues to rise steadily, it appears that the rate of enrollment growth has somewhat moderated in recent times. This observation suggests that the economic downturn has had some impact on the program, potentially limiting its expansion during the analyzed period.

The report's findings highlight the significance of CHIP in providing healthcare coverage to children across the United States. As a crucial lifeline for families, CHIP plays a vital role in ensuring access to affordable healthcare, particularly for those who might not qualify for Medicaid but still require essential medical services for their children.

As the nation continues to grapple with the effects of economic uncertainty, it is essential that policymakers and healthcare stakeholders assess the CHIP program's efficacy and address any barriers to enrollment growth. Strengthening CHIP's reach and impact is paramount to guaranteeing that all children have access to the healthcare they deserve.

To gain a more in-depth understanding of the data presented in this report, please refer to the attached Data Snapshot (.pdf).

This news article underscores the ongoing importance of CHIP in offering healthcare coverage to millions of children nationwide. By monitoring enrollment trends and policy developments, we can ensure that this vital program continues to serve as a lifeline for families in need while adapting to the changing landscape of healthcare.
66.title: CHIP Enrollment: June 2011 Data Snapshot
