67.text:
nt:

(CNN) - Vice President Joe Biden and Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan met in Danville, Kentucky on Thursday evening for the vice presidential debate.

MARTHA RADDATZ, MODERATOR: Good evening, and welcome to the first and only vice presidential debate of 2012, sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates. I'm Martha Raddatz of ABC News, and I am honored to moderate this debate between two men who have dedicated much of their lives to public service.

Tonight's debate is divided between domestic and foreign policy issues. And I'm going to move back and forth between foreign and domestic, since that is what a vice president or president would have to do. We will have nine different segments. At the beginning of each segment, I will ask both candidates a question, and they will each have two minutes to answer. Then I will encourage a discussion between the candidates with follow-up questions.

By coin toss, it has been determined that Vice President Biden will be first to answer the opening question. We have a wonderful audience here at Centre College tonight. You will no doubt hear their enthusiasm at the end of the debate - and right now, as we welcome Vice President Joe Biden and Congressman Paul Ryan. OK, you got your little wave to the families in.

It's great. Good evening, gentlemen. It really is an honor to be here with both of you.

I would like to begin with Libya. On a rather somber note, one month ago tonight, on the anniversary of 9/11, Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other brave Americans were killed in a terrorist attack in Benghazi. The State Department has now made clear, there were no protesters there. It was a pre-planned assault by heavily armed men. Wasn't this a massive intelligence failure, Vice President Biden?

VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN: What is was, it was a tragedy, Martha. It - Chris Stevens was one of our best. We lost three other brave Americans. I can make absolutely two commitments to you and all the American people tonight. One, we will find and bring to justice the men who did this. And secondly, we will get to the bottom of it, and whatever - wherever the facts lead us, wherever they lead us, we will make clear to the American public, because whatever mistakes were made will not be made again.

When you're looking at a president, Martha, it seems to me that you should take a look at his most important responsibility. That's caring for the national security of the country. And the best way to do that is take a look at how he's handled the issues of the day. On Iraq, the president said he would end the war. Governor Romney said that was a tragic mistake, we should have left 30,000 - he ended it. Governor Romney said that was a tragic mistake, we should have left 30,000 troops there.

With regard to Afghanistan, he said he will end the war in 2014. Governor Romney said we should not set a date, number one. And number two, with regard to 2014, it depends. When it came to Osama bin Laden, the president the first day in office, I was sitting with him in the Oval Office, he called in the CIA and signed an order saying, "My highest priority is to get bin Laden."

Prior to the election, prior to the - him being sworn in, said, "I wouldn't move heaven and earth to get bin Laden." He didn't understand it was more than about taking a murderer off the battlefield. It was about restoring America's heart and letting terrorists around the world know, if you do harm to America, we will track you to the gates of hell if need be. And lastly, the president of the United States has - has led with a steady hand and clear vision. Governor Romney, the opposite. The last thing we need now is another war.

RADDATZ: Congressman Ryan? 

RYAN: We mourn the loss of these four Americans who were murdered. When you take a look at what has happened just in the last few weeks, they sent the U.N. ambassador out to say that this was because of a protest and a YouTube video. It took the president two weeks to acknowledge that this was a terrorist attack.

He went to the U.N. and in his speech at the U.N. he said six times - he talked about the YouTube video.

Look, if we're hit by terrorists we're going to call it for what it is, a terrorist attack. Our ambassador in Paris has a Marine detachment guarding him. Shouldn't we have a Marine detachment guarding our ambassador in Benghazi, a place where we knew that there was an Al Qaida cell with arms?

This is becoming more troubling by the day. They first blamed the YouTube video. Now they're trying to blame the Romney-Ryan ticket for making this an issue.

With respect to Iraq, we had the same position before the withdrawal, which was we agreed with the Obama administration. Let's have a status of forces agreement to make sure that we secure our gains. The vice president was put in charge of those negotiations by President Obama and they failed to get the agreement. We don't have a status of forces agreement because they failed to get one. That's what we are talking about.

Now, when it comes to our veterans, we owe them a great debt of gratitude for what they've done for us, including your son Beau. But we also want to make sure that we don't lose the things we fought so hard to get.

Now, with respect to Afghanistan, the 2014 deadline, we agree with a 2014 transition. But what we also want it do is make sure that we're not projecting weakness abroad, and that's what's happening here.

RYAN: This Benghazi issue would be a tragedy in and of itself, but unfortunately it's indicative of a broader problem. And that is what we are watching on our TV screens is the unraveling of the Obama foreign policy, which is making the (inaudible) more chaotic us less safe.

RADDATZ: I just want to you about right in the middle of the crisis. Governor Romney, and you're talking about this again tonight, talked about the weakness; talked about apologies from the Obama administration. Was that really appropriate right in the middle of the crisis?

RYAN: On that same day, the Obama administration had the exact same position. Let's recall that they disavowed their own statement that they had put out earlier in the day in Cairo. So we had the same position, but we will - it's never too early to speak out for our values.

We should have spoken out right away when the green revolution was up and starting; when the mullahs in Iran were attacking their people. We should not have called Bashar Assad a reformer when he was turning his Russian-provided guns on his own people. We should always stand up for peace, for democracy, for individual rights.

And we should not be imposing these devastating defense cuts, because what that does when we equivocate on our values, when we show that we're cutting down on defense, it makes us more weak. It projects weakness. And when we look weak, our adversaries are much more willing to test us. They're more brazen in their attacks, and are allies are less willing to...

[CROSSTALK]

BIDEN: With all due respect, that's a bunch of malarkey.

RADDATZ: And why is that so?

BIDEN: Because not a single thing he said is accurate. First of all...

RADDATZ: Be specific.

BIDEN: I will be very specific. Number one, the - this lecture on embassy security - the congressman here cut embassy security in much for the embassy security piece.

...

(end of article)
67.title: Transcript: Vice Presidential Debate

68.description: Thank you so much Charlie [Rangel]. Thanks for your friendship. Thanks for your leadership. The Congress will miss you when you leave its…
68.text: This article is an edited version of the original speech given by Hillary Clinton on Feb 17, 2016. The content has been condensed and summarized for brevity and clarity.
68.title:
Thank you so much Charlie Rangel for your leadership and friendship. It is an honor to be back here in Harlem and to have the opportunity to address the remarkable accomplishments and challenges faced by the African American community.

Harlem holds a special place in American history as the birthplace of great art, culture and vibrant public life. However, it is important to understand that the narrative of Black America cannot be solely focused on crime, poverty, and challenges. It is crucial to recognize the strength, pride, and achievements that are evident on every street in Harlem and other communities across the country.

While progress has been made in terms of African American success and leadership in various fields, there are still significant barriers that prevent full participation and equality. These barriers have been highlighted recently in the Flint, Michigan water crisis, where predominantly black and poor communities were subjected to poisoned water for almost two years.

The Flint crisis is not an isolated incident. Similar problems persist in communities where people of color and the poor have been left behind. Under-investment, lack of quality education, and limited political power have contributed to the vulnerabilities faced by these communities.

In order to address these barriers and build ladders of opportunity, a comprehensive commitment to equity and opportunity for African American communities is needed. This commitment includes creating jobs, investing in transit and infrastructure, expanding access to capital for black entrepreneurs, ensuring equal pay for equal work, and raising the minimum wage.

Homeownership and access to quality pre-school education are also essential components of this commitment. Additionally, ending the school-to-prison pipeline and focusing on criminal justice reform are crucial steps in dismantling the systemic racism that persists in our society.

This commitment requires holding leaders accountable and ensuring that promises are translated into action. It necessitates a sustained effort to build trust, cooperation, and respect between law enforcement and communities. The right to vote should also be protected, as Republican efforts to impose barriers on black voters continue to threaten our democracy.

It is important for Democrats, especially those asking for votes from the African American community, to acknowledge the realities and concerns of black Americans and to demonstrate a sustained commitment to addressing these issues. White Americans must also listen to and empathize with the experiences and challenges faced by African Americans.

Ending systemic racism is a collective effort that requires contributions from all individuals and communities. It is a moral imperative for us to work towards a society where everyone has equal opportunities and where justice is not determined by the color of one's skin.

In conclusion, it is crucial to recognize the progress that has been made, but also important to acknowledge the work that still needs to be done to break down barriers for African Americans. With sustained commitment, empathy, and a shared sense of purpose, we can build a future that is far better than our past.

69.description: Reiterating a hard-line nationalist approach, Mr. Trump raised new questions about his commitment to automatically defend NATO allies.
69.text:
CLEVELAND — On the eve of accepting the Republican nomination for president, Donald J. Trump has raised concerns regarding his commitment to automatically defend NATO allies in the event of an attack. Trump stated that he would first evaluate their contributions to the alliance before deciding to come to their aid.

When questioned about Russia's threatening activities, particularly affecting the Baltic States, Trump acknowledged that he would assess whether these nations have fulfilled their obligations to the United States before deciding on intervention.

Examining whether NATO allies have met their responsibilities before offering assistance appears to be a departure from traditional American foreign policy. Trump's stance aligns with his previous statements threatening to withdraw American forces from both Europe and Asia if allied nations fail to contribute more to their protection.

The Republican candidate also made it clear that he would not pressure authoritarian allies, such as Turkey, to cease purges of political adversaries or crackdown on civil liberties. Trump suggested that the United States ought to prioritize fixing internal issues before attempting to influence the behavior of other nations.

This marked the first instance where a major candidate for president has proposed conditioning the United States' defense of its major allies. Trump's remarks have added another layer of uncertainty to America's long-standing commitment to the NATO alliance.
69.title: Donald Trump Sets Conditions for Defending NATO Allies Against Attack

70.description: A transcript of an Oval Office interview Friday with President Donald Trump by AP White House Correspondent Julie Pace...
70.text:
In a candid interview in the Oval Office with AP White House Correspondent Julie Pace, President Donald Trump discussed a range of topics, including his first 100 days in office, the release of American charity worker Aya Hijazi, his relationship with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and his plans for tax reform and the renegotiation of NAFTA. Here are the key highlights from the interview:

Release of Aya Hijazi:
President Trump revealed that he had asked the Egyptian government to release Aya Hijazi, an Egyptian-American charity worker who had been detained in Egypt for nearly three years. He stated that he did not strike any deal with Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, but simply asked him to look into the case. President Trump also noted that the release of Hijazi and seven other individuals was a “great thing to see."

Relationship with Angela Merkel:
President Trump spoke highly of his relationship with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, stating that they had "unbelievable chemistry" despite their disagreements on NATO payments and immigration. He discussed an incident in which he had reportedly ignored calls to shake Merkel's hand, stating that he had already shaken her hand four times during their meeting. He emphasized that he had developed great relationships with all world leaders, including el-Sissi.

Perceptions of the Presidency:
President Trump dismissed the significance of the 100-day benchmark, stating that it was an "artificial barrier" that does not hold much meaning. He expressed confidence in the relationships he has established with world leaders and claimed that he should be given high marks for this achievement. According to the President, his interactions with world leaders, particularly his dealings with China, have been positively received, despite criticisms over his approach to NATO and his push for member countries to increase their contributions.

Tax Reform and Obamacare:
President Trump revealed that his administration would be announcing its tax reform plan on Wednesday, aiming to unveil a comprehensive plan for both businesses and individuals. He compared his efforts on healthcare to those of former President Obama, stating that he had been working on healthcare for 60 days, whereas Obama had taken 17 months to pass the Affordable Care Act. He emphasized that his administration is laying the foundation for future policy accomplishments.

Border Wall and NAFTA:
Regarding the border wall with Mexico, President Trump stated that it would be built, either through renegotiation or termination of NAFTA. He indicated that the cost of the wall would be significantly less than the estimated $24 billion, and that he hoped to have it built for $10 billion or less. President Trump also mentioned his administration's goal to crack down on criminal gangs, particularly MS-13, and secure the border to prevent drug trafficking.

Iran Nuclear Deal:
President Trump accused Iran of breaking the "spirit" of the nuclear accord by engaging in destabilizing activities in the Middle East. While he did not explicitly state that the U.S. would withdraw from the deal, he noted that it was a possibility. He declined to comment on discussions with European leaders regarding the agreement.

Dreamers and Immigration:
In response to a question about the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and Dreamers, President Trump stated that his administration's policy is to focus on capturing and deporting criminals, rather than targeting the Dreamers. He assured that Dreamers should "rest easy" and that there are no immediate plans to change their status.

The interview with President Trump covered a wide range of topics, providing insight into his thoughts on foreign policy, immigration, and his first 100 days in office. The President discussed his accomplishments, highlighted his priorities, and emphasized the importance of relationships with world leaders in achieving his goals.
70.title: President Trump Discusses 100 Days, Aya Hijazi, and Foreign Policy in Oval Office Interview with The Associated Press

71.description: I came to Washington to fight for a smaller government and get spending under control, not shut the government down. In fact, I have repeatedly voted to fund the government in the last few days.
71.text:
I came to Washington to fight for a smaller government and get spending under control, not shut the government down. In fact, I have repeatedly voted to fund the government in the last few days.

The shutdown isn't good for anyone in our community or our country. MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa has furloughed more than 1,500 employees, putting our national security at risk before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel sent them back to work this week. Veterans in my district are facing a possible future suspension in claims processing. Tax refunds can't go out. Citrus growers can't access the E-Verify system to ensure work authorization is approved, which limits their hiring ability.

Unfortunately, President Barack Obama and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have been unreasonable and unwilling to negotiate, which led to this government shutdown. We can end this if they would join us at the table and compromise, but Senate leaders and our president won't budge.

I want to be clear: I have never supported Obamacare and have voted more than 40 times to defund it, delay it, or repeal it. I went a step further and introduced an amendment to the continuing resolution that would ensure that the full extent of Obamacare applies to members of Congress, the president, the vice president and staff. The House passed my amendment with bipartisan support. Unfortunately, the Democratic-controlled Senate hasn't passed any of these bills and refused to even vote on my amendment. We are badly mistaken to think there is any hope of the president eliminating his signature legislation, as awful as it is.

Shutting down the government has had zero impact on Obamacare. Unfortunately, some were led to believe that Obamacare would immediately cease if the government shut down. The reality is, however, that despite the government being shut down for multiple days, Obamacare continues to be implemented with all of its glitches and problems. That is because about 70 percent of Obamacare is funded through mandatory funding while the current funding battle only addresses discretionary funding — it doesn't even touch mandatory funding.

Since its grand opening on Oct. 1, Obamacare has been an abject failure. Countless technical glitches have prevented enrollees from accessing the online exchanges, and there are endless reports of consumer sticker shock from the high cost of Obamacare insurance premiums. Americans deserve to know that Obamacare is a disaster. Yet these failures and many more have been overshadowed by the government shutdown and the debate over a continuing resolution that, by law, could never fully defund Obamacare.

Obamacare will fall under its own weight of complexities, costs, and inconsistencies, all at the expense of the American people. The best way to repeal Obamacare is to let it take effect, point out its impact, win control of the Senate, and elect a president who will support its repeal.

In the few years since I was elected to Congress in 2010, we have achieved huge savings and taken monumental steps. For the first time since the Korean War, total federal spending has gone down for two years in a row. We need to continue to take steps forward, shedding off our "excessive funding weight" one pound at a time. That is why I would support a continuing resolution that funds the government at sequestration levels for one year.

We need to get the government running again and end this shutdown so that our communities can get back on their feet.

Rep. Dennis Ross, R-Lakeland, represents the 15th Congressional District that covers part of western Polk and eastern Hillsborough counties, including Brandon and the University of South Florida. He wrote this column exclusively for the Tampa Bay Times.
71.title: Rep. Ross: We Need to Get Government Running Again

The Ohio Art Company Announces Sale of Etch A Sketch Brand

In a strategic move to focus on its metal lithography business and invest in manufacturing operations in Bryan, the Ohio Art Company has announced the sale of its beloved Etch A Sketch and Doodle Sketch brands. The sale of these iconic toys will allow the company to further establish itself as one of the premier metal lithographers in North America.

With its first lithography press installed back in 1912, the Ohio Art Company has been a leader in precision printing, known for its beautiful color reproduction and durability against stamping and fabrication processes. The company aims to continue building its reputation in this field under the leadership of CEO Elena West.

Alongside the brand sale, the Ohio Art Company emphasizes its ongoing commitment to the Bryan, Ohio community. Collaborating with local leaders, the company has actively worked to optimize resources at its Bryan facility. G&M Media Packaging and Reece Brothers Digital Printers have become tenants, while Wilton Keck Recycling has acquired warehouse space for its new commercial recycling venture. Additionally, the company has leased warehouse space to two local manufacturers in need of staging support.

Martin Killgallon, President of the Ohio Art Company, expresses satisfaction with the partnerships formed with local businesses, as these collaborations not only provide quality space and support but also help retain jobs within the Bryan community. The company looks forward to further collaboration with other local businesses, as its commitment to the community remains a crucial element of its strategy.

The Etch A Sketch and Doodle Sketch brands have been acquired by Spin Master Corp., a leading global children’s entertainment company. Spin Master's expertise lies in creating, designing, manufacturing, and marketing a diverse portfolio of innovative toys, games, products, and entertainment properties. Assuring the continuation of Etch A Sketch's legacy, Elena West concludes by expressing her delight that children worldwide will continue to enjoy one of the most iconic toys ever created.
72.title: Sale of the Etch A Sketch Brand

73.description: As hype around Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders grows, political opponents and media reporters are once
73.text:
As the hype around Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders continues to grow, political opponents and media reporters are once again suggesting that the socialist Vermont senator is a gun nut. CNN's Jake Tapper brought up this issue in an interview with Sanders on July 5, alluding to an attack ad by a pro-Martin O'Malley group that claimed Sanders voted against the Brady Bill, which included background checks and waiting periods for gun purchases.

The Brady Act, which became a landmark piece of gun control legislation, mandated a five-day waiting period for anyone wanting to buy a handgun while local law enforcement conducted criminal background checks. Before the bill became law, it underwent several transformations. Sanders, who was elected to the House of Representatives in 1990, voted on it multiple times, almost always in opposition.

In May 1991, Sanders voted against a version of the bill that mandated a seven-day waiting period for background checks, but the bill passed in the House. The Senate later decreased the waiting period to five days, and in November 1991, Sanders again voted against that version. Although it passed in the House, it did not receive enough votes in the Senate. The bill remained in limbo during 1992.

After several amendments, a version of the bill was reintroduced that reinstated the five-day waiting period. In November 1993, Sanders once again voted against that version but voted for an amendment that imposed an instant background check instead (although the technology for instant checks did not exist at the time). He also voted against an amendment that would have ended state waiting periods but voted for an amendment giving those denied a gun the right to know why.

The final compromise version of the Brady bill, which included an interim five-day waiting period while an instant background check system was installed, was passed and signed into law on November 30, 1993. Sanders voted against it.

Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, explained that Sanders opposed the Brady bill for two reasons. First, he believed that a national waiting period was federal overreach. Second, he was representing the will of the people of Vermont.

Sanders' home state, Vermont, has a high gun ownership rate and lenient gun control laws. Sanders' voting record on guns reflects the preferences of his constituents, as well as his own personal views.

Experts agree that Sanders' stance on guns is more moderate compared to his Democratic rivals. While he advocates for more gun regulation than the current U.S. policies, he recognizes the preferences of his constituents and does not prioritize gun control as a key issue.

Overall, the claim made in the attack ad that Bernie Sanders voted against the Brady Bill and background checks and waiting periods is mostly true. Sanders did vote against the bill multiple times, but he also voted in favor of an amendment that included an instant background check and against repealing state background checks.
73.title: Did Bernie Sanders Vote Against Background Checks and Waiting Periods for Gun Purchases?

In a recent address from the Rose Garden, President mentioned the need for an all-of-the-above strategy for American energy. The strategy aims to produce more oil and gas domestically while also focusing on biofuels, fuel-efficient cars, solar power, wind power, and other renewable energy sources.

Additionally, the President recommended granting the agency overseeing oil markets new authority to protect against volatility and excessive speculation.

While acknowledging that these steps alone will not immediately reduce gas prices, the President believes they are essential in preventing market manipulation and safeguarding American consumers. In the meantime, his administration will take executive actions to analyze and investigate trading activities in energy markets and implement consumer protections under Wall Street reform more efficiently.

The President concluded by reiterating his commitment to pursuing an all-of-the-above strategy for American energy to break the cycle of price spikes year after year. In an energetic and passionate speech in El Paso, Texas, President addressed comprehensive immigration reform and the need for a fair and just system. He emphasized that America has always been a nation of immigrants, welcoming those who are willing to embrace its ideals and contribute to its success.

While the President acknowledged the challenges and complexity of immigration reform, he urged politicians to put aside politics and work towards finding common ground. He called for accountability for businesses that exploit undocumented workers and stated that those who are in the country illegally should pay their taxes, learn English, and undergo a background check before being considered for legalization.

The President also expressed the need for visa reform and making it easier for talented individuals to start businesses and create jobs in the United States. He urged Congress to pass the DREAM Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for young undocumented immigrants who were brought to the country as children.

The President concluded his speech by calling on the American people to add their voices to the debate and push for comprehensive immigration reform. He emphasized that reform is about unleashing the potential and dreams of individuals like José Hernández, highlighting his journey from a migrant farmworker to becoming an astronaut for NASA.

The President expressed his commitment to leading a civil and constructive debate on immigration reform and urged Congress to catch up with the growing coalition of leaders and Americans who support comprehensive reform.

79.description: The mogul/candidate’s rant on border crossers is on the minds of laborers there, some who say they originally came to the country illegally.
79.text:
nt:  
For weeks, construction workers from Latin America have been diligently working on the site of the Old Post Office Pavilion in downtown Washington, proud to be building one of the city's newest luxury hotels. However, tensions have risen on the job site after billionaire developer Donald Trump, the man behind the project, made controversial comments about illegal immigration while launching his bid for the Republican presidential nomination. This has left some of the workers concerned about their job security and others disgusted by the opinions of the man responsible for creating those jobs.

According to several workers at the site, it is possible that some of the construction workers, who are undocumented immigrants, were hired by a Trump company to finish the $200 million hotel. While a Trump spokeswoman has stated that the company and its contractors abide by all applicable laws, the workers are now worried about the repercussions of Trump's comments. They argue that they have lived honest lives, worked hard, and contributed to the local community, including buying homes and raising U.S.-born children.

Several of the laborers, who come from countries such as El Salvador, Honduras, and Guatemala, have become U.S. citizens or obtained legal status through immigration programs targeting Central Americans fleeing civil wars or natural disasters. Others quietly admitted that they remain in the country illegally.

The concern among the workers is that Trump's comments could escalate into a bigger problem and potentially lead to their termination. Some workers even expressed the fear of being told to "get the heck out of here" by Trump himself. They argue that they risk their lives and health on the job site, and Trump's comments do not accurately reflect their hard work and dedication.

In response to the allegations, Hope Hicks, a spokeswoman for the Trump Organization, emphasized that the company and its contractors follow all immigration laws when hiring workers. She also stated that the obligation to check the workers' status lies with the lead contractor, Lend Lease, who is responsible for hiring subcontractors for the project.

The controversy surrounding Trump's comments and his stance on illegal immigration highlights the complexity of the issue. While his remarks resonated with conservative voters, they have also led to backlash from the general electorate and businesses that are concerned about alienating the Latino community. Trump's comments have already resulted in severed ties with corporations such as NBC and Macy's.

At the construction site, workers continue with their responsibilities despite the tension. Many of them expressed their disagreement with Trump's comments and emphasized that they are hardworking individuals striving to build a better life for their families. They believe that their contribution to society and their commitment to their jobs make them more American than Trump himself.
79.title: Immigrant Workers at Trump Hotel Site Express Concerns over Job Security

In the aftermath of the terrorist attack in Brussels, Hillary Clinton highlighted the need for steady leadership and solidarity with European allies in the fight against ISIS. Speaking at Stanford University, Clinton emphasized the importance of a comprehensive strategy to defeat ISIS and keep Americans safe.

Clinton began by expressing gratitude to her hosts and reflecting on personal connections to Stanford. She then addressed the recent attack in Brussels, emphasizing the urgent nature of the fight against ISIS. She recognized the victims of the attack and highlighted the need to respond firmly to the threat of terrorism.

ISIS poses a significant challenge as it operates in multiple theaters and constantly adapts its tactics. Clinton outlined a three-part plan to defeat ISIS: intensifying the coalition air campaign in Iraq and Syria, dismantling the global network that supports ISIS, and strengthening defenses and resilience at home.

Clinton stressed the need for intelligence surge and technological advancements to stay ahead of ISIS. She called for closer collaboration with intelligence agencies, cybersecurity experts, and technology professionals to track and analyze ISIS's online activities.

The former Secretary of State emphasized the importance of alliances in combating terrorism. She highlighted the contributions of NATO allies and the need for the United States to support and strengthen these alliances. Clinton also indicated the significance of European partners in sharing intelligence and preventing attacks both in Europe and the United States.

To address the global challenges posed by extremism, Clinton proposed solutions such as supporting ceasefires in Syria and working with coalition partners and opposition forces to create safe areas within the country. She also called for greater coordination and information sharing among European nations to prevent the flow of foreign fighters.

Moreover, Clinton stressed the need for effective strategies that do not demonize all Muslims or resort to torture. She emphasized the importance of building trust with American Muslim communities and recognizing their role in countering radicalization. Clinton also condemned offensive rhetoric and emphasized the power of alliances and partnerships in the fight against ISIS.

In conclusion, Clinton urged for strong, smart, and steady leadership to prevail against ISIS. She expressed confidence in the ability of the United States, along with its allies, to defeat ISIS and reaffirmed America's commitment to its values and principles.

The first presidential debate of the 2012 campaign season took place on Wednesday night at the University of Denver in Denver, Colorado. President Obama highlighted his administration's accomplishments in job creation, including the revival of the auto industry and the rise in housing. He emphasized the need to invest in education, develop new sources of energy, and reduce the deficit in a balanced way.

Governor Romney outlined his plan to boost American energy production, crack down on China's unfair trade practices, improve education, and champion small businesses. He disagreed with President Obama's tax plan, stating that he would not reduce taxes for high-income individuals and that his number one priority was job growth.

The discussion then shifted to the topic of taxes and the deficit. President Obama criticized Governor Romney's tax plan, stating that it would add $5 trillion to the deficit and burden the middle class. He highlighted the need for a balanced approach that includes both spending cuts and revenue increases. Governor Romney countered by stating that he did not have a $5 trillion tax cut and that his plan would not add to the deficit. He emphasized the importance of cutting spending, lowering taxes, and growing the economy.

The debate concluded with a discussion on the Simpson-Bowles deficit reduction plan. Governor Romney stated that he had his own plan and criticized President Obama for not adopting the Simpson-Bowles plan during his presidency. President Obama defended his approach, stating that he had made adjustments to the plan and was currently putting it forward before Congress.

86.description: Jake Tapper interviews former President Bill Clinton on ABC News' "This Week."
86.text:
April 18, 2010 — Former President Bill Clinton recently granted an exclusive interview with "This Week," where he addressed various topics including his mistakes as president, the dangers of political rhetoric, Supreme Court nominations, Middle East peace negotiations, and the upcoming midterm elections.

One of the main topics discussed was the recent accusation by conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh that Clinton "set the stage for violence" with a speech regarding political rhetoric. Clinton firmly dismissed Limbaugh's accusation, stating that it "doesn't make any sense." He emphasized that while political dissent and argument are crucial in democracy, individuals must also take responsibility for the potential consequences of their words. Clinton expressed concern about threats against President Obama and Congress, cautioning against careless language that could incite violence.

Reflecting on his presidency, Clinton admitted to making mistakes in relation to financial regulation. He acknowledged that he was wrong to have taken the advice of his Treasury secretaries, Robert Rubin and Larry Summers, on the issue of unregulated financial instruments called derivatives. Clinton now recognizes that their argument, which claimed that derivatives did not require further regulation due to being expensive and limited to a small group of sophisticated investors, was flawed. He expressed regret for not attempting to regulate derivatives during his time in office, attributing the lack of action to the Republican majority in Congress.

Regarding the nomination of the next Supreme Court justice, Clinton offered advice to President Obama. He suggested that a robe should not be a requirement for the position, stating that it is important for the nominee to be smart, competent, and understand the lives of ordinary people. Clinton recommended considering diversity in the selection process, including representation of different religions and genders on the court.

Clinton expressed his satisfaction with the passage of the health care reform bill, likening his feelings to how Teddy Roosevelt would have felt seeing his cousin Franklin sign legislation in areas he had advocated. He and his wife, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, personally lobbied for the passage of the bill.

Commenting on the upcoming midterm elections, Clinton drew parallels to the political climate of 1994 when Democrats faced major losses in Congress. While he acknowledged the intense political dissent, he predicted that the outcome of the election would be less dramatic than in '94, stating that he did not believe Republicans would win either house.

In terms of the Middle East peace process, Clinton refrained from giving public advice to President Obama to keep his options open, but stressed the need to push both sides to engage in serious negotiations. He expressed his willingness to strongly support any peace plan proposed by the administration, even if it faced resistance.

In conclusion, Bill Clinton's interview covered a range of topics, from admitting to mistakes in financial regulation to discussing the dangers of political rhetoric and offering advice on the Supreme Court nomination, Middle East peace process, and upcoming midterm elections.
86.title: Bill Clinton Reflects on Mistakes, Political Rhetoric, and Current Issues

In a recent campaign rally, Mitt Romney expressed his support for coal miners and their jobs, emphasizing the importance of coal-fired power plants in Ohio and the surrounding areas. Romney argued that the environmental regulations implemented by President Barack Obama's administration could potentially lead to job losses and increased electricity costs for residents of Ohio.

However, the Obama campaign quickly responded to Romney's statements, asserting that his position on coal has drastically changed since his time as the governor of Massachusetts. The Obama campaign highlighted three key statements made by Romney during a heated debate over the future of the Salem Harbor Power Station, a coal-burning plant in Boston:

1. "That plant kills people" - Romney's reference to Salem Harbor Power Station.
2. "I will not create jobs that kill people" - Romney's commitment to prioritizing public health over job creation.
3. "If the choice is between dirty power plants or protecting the health of the people of Massachusetts, there is no choice in my mind. I will always come down on the side of public health" - Romney's unwavering stance on safeguarding public health.

It is important to note that Massachusetts had implemented new rules in 2001 to reduce emissions from power plants, including nitrogen oxide, sulfur dioxide, carbon dioxide, and mercury. Salem Harbor Power Station was among the plants singled out as significant polluters, and a Harvard study estimated that it caused various health issues, including premature deaths, emergency room visits, asthma attacks, and upper respiratory symptoms.

While some individuals disputed the figures from the Harvard study, claiming they were based on unproven modeling, the study's methodology has since been replicated and is respected by health scientists. Romney, at the time, seemed to accept these findings, as evidenced by his own statements in news releases and his hiring of environmental experts from the Conservation Law Foundation.

To ascertain the accuracy of the Obama campaign's claim and the severity of Romney's views on coal emissions, experts and environmentalists were consulted. They confirmed that Romney's condemnation of the Salem Harbor plant was part of his wider commitment to emissions reductions, which aligns with the standards later proposed by the U.S. EPA, the same standards Romney now criticizes.

Furthermore, an analysis comparing the emissions levels of Salem Harbor Power Station to those of coal-fired plants in the Midwest revealed that the former had lower or comparable emissions of nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxide, two pollutants known to be hazardous to health. This implies that if one were to support the regulations Romney advocated for in 2003, they would likely also support similar measures on a national scale.

In conclusion, while Romney made reference to a specific power plant, his comments were part of a broader emissions-reduction initiative that he championed as governor, indicating a consistent viewpoint on coal emissions and public health. Therefore, the Obama campaign's claim about Romney's stance on coal, although focusing on a single plant, holds significant truth based on historical records and contextual analysis.

On the Truth-O-Meter, the claim made by the Obama campaign rates Mostly True.
87.title: Barack Obama Claims Mitt Romney Condemned Coal-fired Power Plants as "Killers"

88.description: UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, has welcomed news of the arrival in the United States this week of the 10,000<sup>th</sup> refugee from the conflict in Syria,
88.text:
UNHCR, the UN Refugee Agency, warmly welcomes the news of the 10,000th Syrian refugee settling in the United States this week and urges greater global solidarity ahead of upcoming summits focused on addressing the unprecedented refugee crisis worldwide.

Acknowledging the United States' longstanding tradition of offering sanctuary to people fleeing persecution, Shelly Pitterman, the UNHCR Regional Representative in the United States, commended the nation's leadership, stating, "The arrival of the 10,000th Syrian refugee marks yet another testament to this exemplary initiative."

Expressing gratitude towards the communities in the United States that have willingly opened their doors, Pitterman also recognized the tireless efforts of civil society partners in facilitating humanitarian aid. Nonetheless, he emphasized the urgent need for increased support for Syrian refugees and the global crisis, which has witnessed an unparalleled number of individuals seeking refuge from persecution.

As of the end of 2015, a staggering 65.3 million people, driven by war, conflict, and persecution, were forcibly displaced worldwide—a record high. Among them, the Syrian refugee crisis stands as the most extensive, with over 4.8 million Syrians seeking sanctuary in neighboring countries. Regrettably, these host countries are already strained, causing an increasing number of refugees to live below national poverty lines.

To assist the most vulnerable amongst the displaced population and to alleviate some of the burden on countries hosting refugees, UNHCR has called upon governments to offer resettlement to those facing the highest risks. Thus far, resettlement countries have pledged more than 220,000 places for Syrians through resettlement and other humanitarian admission programs. It is estimated that approximately 40 percent of the 1.19 million refugees globally requiring resettlement—roughly 478,000 Syrians—are in urgent need of a new home.

Recognizing the limited opportunities for resettlement, UNHCR reserves this option for individuals who are most at risk, such as unaccompanied children, women-headed households, victims of torture, and those with special medical needs. In an effort to ensure the safety and security of all refugees accepted for resettlement, the UNHCR meticulously screens and identifies suitable candidates before referring them to their receiving country. In the case of the United States, all referred refugees undergo a rigorous process, including face-to-face interviews with Department of Homeland Security officers, extensive identity checks, and multiple security screenings.

UNHCR urges a collective global effort to provide Syrian refugees with more safe and regular pathways for admission. The upcoming United Nations General Assembly Summit for Refugees and Migrants on September 19th and the President of the United States Summit on Refugees on September 20th will provide platforms for countries to demonstrate solidarity with refugee-hosting nations worldwide by offering legal avenues for Syrian and other vulnerable refugee groups to access safety and protection through resettlement and other admission programs.

"Resettlement, supported by continued humanitarian funding, is a vital form of solidarity with countries hosting refugees and should be expanded on a global scale," emphasized Pitterman.
88.title: UN Refugee Agency Celebrates Arrival of 10,000th Syrian Refugee Resettled in the United States

89.description: Under attack at a recent debate from rival Hillary Clinton on health care, Barack Obama shot back: "Well, let's talk abo
89.text:
Under attack at a recent debate from rival Hillary Clinton on health care, Barack Obama shot back with a claim that he provides universal health care. However, a closer look at his plan reveals that it falls short of a guaranteed universal coverage.

Both Democratic presidential candidates share a lot in common when it comes to health care, but one key difference is Clinton's inclusion of a universal mandate. This means that individuals would be legally required to purchase health insurance. Obama's plan, on the other hand, only includes a mandate to insure children and lacks a mandate for adults, similar to the plans proposed by Clinton and Edwards. According to health policy expert Kenneth Thorpe, this difference is likely to result in fewer people being insured under Obama's plan.

Obama's decision to exclude a mandate for adults is seen as a more cautious approach to avoid penalizing those with modest incomes. If premiums do not decrease significantly after implementing reforms, these individuals may still be unable to afford insurance. Obama argues that mandating them to buy insurance, and subsequently fining them if they don't comply, would only punish the poor and leave them uninsured. Instead, he believes that his plan will lower costs enough to persuade a large number of the estimated 47 million uninsured Americans to voluntarily sign up, with a mandate potentially being added later on.

Although Obama claims his plan will create market conditions for universal availability of health care, it does not guarantee it. While his approach may lead to increased coverage, nothing in his plan provides an assurance of universal health care. Therefore, his claim is considered Barely True.
89.title: Obama's Claim of Universal Health Care Challenged

90.description: When China destroyed its own satellite, outrageand debrisrapidly encircled the globe. Was the Sat Kill a policy weapon or the start of an arms race in space?
90.text:
At 5:28 PM EST on Jan. 11, 2007, a satellite arced over southern China. It was small—just 6 ft. long—a tiny object in the heavens, steadily bleeping its location to ground stations below, just as it had every day for the past seven years. And then it was gone, transformed into a cloud of debris hurtling at nearly 16,000 mph along the main thoroughfare used by orbiting spacecraft.

It was not the start of the world's first war in space, but it could have been. It was just a test: The satellite was a defunct Chinese weather spacecraft. And the country that destroyed it was China. According to reports, a mobile launcher at the Songlin test facility near Xichang, in Sichuan province, lofted a multistage solid-fuel missile topped with a kinetic kill vehicle. Traveling nearly 18,000 mph, the kill vehicle intercepted the sat and—boom—obliterated it. "It was almost just a dead-reckoning flight with little control over the intercept path," says Phillip S. Clark, an independent British authority who has written widely on the Chinese and Russian space programs.

For China, a nation that has already sent humans into space and developed intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), the technology involved in the test was hardly remarkable. But as a demonstration of a rising military posture, it was a surprisingly aggressive act, especially since China has long pushed for an international treaty banning space weapons. "The move was a dangerous step toward the abyss of weaponizing space," says Theresa Hitchens, director of the Center for Defense Information, an independent defense research group in Washington, D.C. "China held the moral high ground about space, and that test re-energized the China hawks in Congress. If we're not careful, space could become the new Wild West. You don't just go and blow things up there." In fact, after the Chinese test, India publicly stepped up its development of anti-satellite technology. And some Israeli officials have argued that, given China's record of selling missile technology to Iran, Israel should develop its own program.

INTERNATIONAL THREAT

For many countries, the most disturbing aspect of the test was not the potentially destabilizing sat kill, but the resulting debris, which poses a serious threat to every satellite in orbit, as well as to the International Space Station. "Space debris is a huge problem," says Laura Grego, staff scientist in the Global Security Program at the Union of Concerned Scientists. "A 1-centimeter object is very hard to track but can do considerable damage if it collides with any spacecraft at a high rate of speed." Think of a shotgun pellet traveling at 10 times the speed of a bullet, smashing into a device built to be as light as possible. And then consider that China's antisatellite (ASAT) test produced as many as 35,000 of these pellets, or pieces of debris, in the 1-cm range. Nearly 1500 pieces were 10 cm and larger.

Although the United States knew that China was planning to test ASAT technology, administration officials—reluctant to disclose the level of U.S. surveillance—chose to say nothing. China failed two or three times before successfully launching the missile in January. All the attempts were observed by the U.S. Air Force satellite system known as the Defense Support Program. Infrared telescopes on these 33-ft.-high defense satellites can spot the plumes from rockets launched anywhere on Earth.

Battlefield: Space Media Platforms Design Team

1] Songlin test facility, near Xichang, Sichuan province, China. Publicly available satellite images of the facility were censored by China prior to the test; immediately following, they were declassified.

2] Experts believe a four-stage, solidÂ­-fuel launch vehicle—thought by American officials to be based on China's KT-2—boosted the kill vehicle into orbit.

3] The Feng-Yun 1C target vehicle was launched May 10, 1999, with a two-year active life span. The 1650-pound polar-orbiting weather satellite was equipped with two 10-band scanning radiometers for Earth observation.

4] The kinetic-energy kill vehicle was traveling nearly 18,000 mph when it struck the satellite.

5] The collision blasted debris throughout low Earth orbit. Within 7 hours, a band of debris had spread halfway around the globe.

Some details of China's ASAT test are classified. Our artist relied on published reports, declassified information, and comparable technology to create this graphic. The Chinese kinetic kill vehicle is based on Raytheon's Exoatmospheric Kill Vehicle. (Diagram by Golden Section Graphics. Inset satellite photograph by Digital Globe.)

Media Platforms Design Team

AMERICA'S OWN SAT KILLS

Every industrialized country relies on satellites every day, for everything from computer networking technology to telecommunications, navigation, weather prediction, television, and radio. This makes satellites especially vulnerable targets. Imagine the U.S. military suddenly without guidance for its soldiers and weapons systems, and its civilians without storm warnings or telephones.

Some satellites, however, are at greater risk than others. Most spacecraft—including spy sats—are in low Earth orbit, which stretches 1240 miles into space. As the Chinese test proved, such targets could be hit with medium-range missiles tipped with crude kill devices. GPS satellites are far higher, orbiting at about 12,600 miles. Many communications sats are in the 22,000-mile range. Destroying them requires a much more powerful and sophisticated long-range ballistic missile—yet it can be done. "You'd need a sky-sweeping capability to comprehensively negate a space support system that is scattered all over," says John Pike, a space analyst at GlobalSecurity.org. "You'd need ICBM-size boosters—hundreds of them."

Such an all-out satellite war would render space useless for decades to come. "There'd be so much debris up there," Clark says, "that it wouldn't be safe to put anything up in space."

The United States and Russia, the two countries with proven ASAT capabilities, have long steered clear of satellites as military targets. Even during the Cold War, spy sats were hands-off; the consequences of destroying them were greater than those of unwelcome surveillance. "The consensus," Clark says, "was that anybody could look at anybody else."

Diagram: China's anti-satellite strike took place at an altitude of 537 miles, which places the international spacecraft depicted below well within range of China's space arsenal.

Nevertheless, the U.S. military has spent decades designing weapons capable of killing other countries' satellites. The crudest American ASAT test, code-named Starfish Prime, took place in 1962, when the U.S. Air Force detonated a 1.4-megaton nuclear weapon at an altitude of 250 miles. The explosion, which occurred about 800 miles west of Hawaii, disabled at least six U.S. and foreign satellites—roughly a third of the world's low Earth orbit total. The resulting electromagnetic pulse knocked out 300 streetlights in Oahu. Clearly, nukes worked as ASAT weapons, but far too indiscriminately.

To develop a more surgical capability, the Air Force launched Project Mudflap, which was designed to destroy individual Soviet satellites with missiles. But inaccurate space-guidance systems plagued early tests. Then, on May 23, 1963, the Air Force pulled off a successful intercept with a modified Nike-Zeus ballistic missile launched from Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands. It took out a rendezvous and docking target for NASA's Gemini missions at an altitude of 150 miles.

Over the next several decades, the Air Force graduated to more sophisticated air-launched missiles that could hit targets with far better accuracy. In 1985, the United States destroyed an American solar observation satellite using a three-stage, heat-seeking miniature vehicle fired from an F-15 fighter jet. That test, like the Chinese one earlier this year, used a kinetic kill vehicle that spewed debris into space. Funding for the program was canceled before the air-launched system could be perfected.

That same year, at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico, the Air Force began operating the powerful Mid-Infrared Chemical Laser. In 1997, it was used to temporarily blind sensors on an Air Force missile-launch and tracking satellite. The sat remained intact; no debris was created. And no laser tests have been conducted since. However, the current federal budget includes funding for a laser to be fired at a low Earth orbit sat from the Starfire Optical Range at Kirtland Air Force Base, in New Mexico, later this year.

Some $400 million has been spent in recent years to develop another sophisticated kill vehicle—a three-stage missile that smacks an enemy's craft with a sheet of Mylar plastic, disabling it without producing any debris. It has yet to be fully tested and would only work on satellites in low Earth orbit; communication and GPS sats are too high.

Destroying an adversary's satellites has far-reaching implications. Do you take out only military sats or so-called civilian ones, too? Nearly every satellite has dual uses: A civilian weather satellite used for tracking hurricanes also could watch military movements. Many satellites are used by multiple nations. And once a nation disables an adversary's satellites, it puts its own in peril. As Charles Vick, a senior analyst at GlobalSecurity says, "It's an act of war."

U.S. Sat Kill Arsenal

- Perhaps the most spectacular test—known as Starfish Prime—occurred on July 9, 1962, when a 1.4-megaton nuclear warhead was detonated 250 miles above the Pacific. Radiation and electromagnetic pulses disabled at least six satellites and created an eerie, artificial glow for 20 minutes.

- The U.S. conducted its only direct antisat test in 1985 when an F-15 climbed to 80,000 ft., then fired a three-stage missile. It caught up to a 17,500-mph Solwind solar observation satellite at an altitude of nearly 300 miles over Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

- In 1997, the U.S. Army hover-tested a kinetic energy weapon that could act like a space-age fly swatter. The kill vehicle extends a Mylar sheet to disable satellites without destroying them. The military found the technology too messy and eventually canceled the program.

- The XSS-11 microsatellite isn't an antisat—but it could be. First launched in April 2005, the spacecraft is designed to circumnavigate targets and relay diagnostic data. Some experts note that it wouldn't be difficult to reprogram the craft to ram into enemy targets.

SENDING A MESSAGE

So why did China risk provoking international hostility? The country's government has been opaque. "The experiment is not targeted at any other country," said a foreign ministry spokeswoman in Beijing.

Some experts think at least part of China's motivation lies in an unclassified 2006 U.S. report on the future of military activities in space. The document reaffirms that "The United States considers space capabilities... vital to its national interests. Consistent with this policy, the United States will: preserve its rights, capabilities, and freedom of action in space; dissuade or deter others from either impeding those rights or developing capabilities intended to do so... and deny, if necessary, adversaries the use of space capabilities hostile to U.S. national interests."

The United States "basically said it has the right to restrict the use of space to only its allies," Clark says. Adds Jeffrey G. Lewis, an arms control expert at the New America Foundation: "Much of the world was appalled at the tone of the policy. One British newspaper columnist basically said it made space the 51st state."

In that context, some experts say, the Chinese test was an effort to force the issue, to show the United States the potential consequences of refusing to negotiate a favorable treaty on the military use of space. "The U.S. was restricting all these arms treaties," says Michael O'Hanlon, a senior fellow in security studies at the Brookings Institution, a Washington, D.C., think tank. "For the Chinese, [the test] was an effort to deal from a position of strength."

Pike believes China may have another rationale for flexing its space muscle: Taiwan. China has long yearned to reabsorb the breakaway island state, which the United States has pledged to defend. In the short term, Pike says, China has only two strategies that could lead to a Taiwan takeover. It could bluff the U.S. in a nuclear confrontation, or it could try something altogether different: Fire medium-range missiles from mobile launchers, just as it did in the January test, and take out America's low-flying imaging satellites. Doing so might blind U.S. military planners long enough for Chinese military forces to gain a foothold on the island.

"The Chinese stage these big amphibious exercises off Taiwan all the time. One day, maybe it'll be real," Pike says. "Either the U.S. will get there quickly enough to stop them or the Chinese will win the race and there won't be the American political resolve to kick them out. All the Chinese would need is time." A half-dozen sats, Pike says—that's all it would take. "Those satellites are low-hanging fruit. It's a no-brainer."

In that scenario, the ASAT test was not really about China showing the United States its capability. It was about China confirming that its war plan is feasible.

AMERICA'S TRUMP CARD

The long-term ramifications of the test will take years to play out, but, for now, few observers think China scored any gains. "It was a mistake," O'Hanlon says. It fueled American hard-liners who want to restrict American technological cooperation with China. And, "It doesn't help China's case saying it isn't a threatening military power," Vick says. "It is a threat, and the test showed that." Whether the United States suddenly accelerates its ASAT capability beyond the testing phase remains to be seen. The country is in the midst of a war; budgets are already tight. Russia is not perceived as a threat, and China has only 60 satellites—few of these are worth shooting down.

America's most robust ASAT weapons were not designed for destroying satellites at all—they are missiles developed and operated by the Missile Defense Agency (MDA), formerly known as the Strategic Defense Initiative. All U.S. ballistic missiles are actually dual-use, and while their ability to shoot down incoming rockets has been proven only in tests, it would be easy to direct them against any low Earth orbit satellite. Twenty-four MDA missiles are operational in Alaska and California, far more than would be needed, Pike says, to handle any immediate ASAT needs. There is, he says, "just nothing to shoot at."

For now, that is. The militarization of space has long been debated. With one blown-up old weather satellite, China has made the prospect of a new arms race far more likely. It showed the world that it is willing to go toe-to-toe up in the final frontier.

Waste Mismanagement IMPACT + ONE DAY It takes only 24 hours for debris to spread along the destroyed satellite's sun-synchronous polar orbit. The force of the impact drives debris into higher and lower orbits, but most of the wreckage remains at the satellite's original altitude.

JULY 2007 The debris ring broadens and begins to mix with satellites and the abundant trash in low Earth orbit, which extends to an altitude of about 1240 miles.

JANUARY 2008 A year after the test, the debris field continues to spread, joining the cloud of general space junk, which includes everything from 10-ton rocket boosters to radioactive droplets of sodium potassium coolant from the nuclear cores of Soviet satellites.

It's called the Kessler Syndrome—the point at which low Earth orbit becomes so crowded with debris that collisions render space unusable. "Debris accumulates over time and takes decades to decay," says Dr. T.S. Kelso of the Center for Space Standards and Innovation. "We can't track the smaller pieces, so there is even more out there than we know." The graphic at left illustrates the density of junk in orbit up to an altitude of 22,000 miles—and Kessler's looming threat.
90.title: China's Space Threat: How Missiles Could Target U.S. Satellites

91.description: When he doesn't know a camera's rolling, the GOP candidate shows his disdain for half of America.
91.text:
During a private fundraiser earlier this year, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney made controversial remarks about voters who support President Barack Obama. In the secret video obtained by Mother Jones, Romney can be heard dismissing Obama supporters as freeloaders who pay no taxes and believe that the government should take care of them. He suggests that these individuals lack personal responsibility and are dependent on the government.

Romney stated that there are 47 percent of the people who will vote for Obama no matter what, referring to them as people who are dependent upon the government and consider themselves victims. He argued that they believe they are entitled to healthcare, food, housing, and other benefits provided by the government. Romney added that these individuals do not pay income taxes.

The video also revealed Romney's views on other topics. He commented on his family background, expressing that if his father had been born to Mexican parents, he would have a better chance at winning the election. Romney emphasized his self-made millionaire status and stated that being born in America with privileges was the greatest gift one could have.

Romney acknowledged that he was facing challenges in winning over Hispanic voters but believed that women were open to supporting him. He advised the donors at the fundraiser to raise millions of dollars to support his campaign.

The Republican candidate revealed that his campaign was hesitant to attack Obama aggressively, as they did not want to alienate independent voters who had previously supported the president. Romney indicated that his campaign aimed to convince these voters that Obama's policies had failed, without vilifying the president.

Romney boasted about the experienced consultants on his team, mentioning that some had worked with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He expressed confidence that winning the election would lead to economic growth and positive market reactions.

During the fundraiser, Romney stated that the campaign purposefully limited the appearances of his wife, Ann Romney, so that people would not get tired of her. He also turned down an invitation from Saturday Night Live, as he believed it would make him appear slapstick and not presidential.

These remarks by Romney, made in the presence of wealthy donors, were considered controversial and showed a different side of him compared to his public campaign messaging. The video caused significant backlash and raised questions about Romney's views and ability to relate to a broad spectrum of voters.
91.title: SECRET VIDEO: Romney Tells Millionaire Donors What He REALLY Thinks of Obama Voters

92.description: In an exclusive interview with ABC News, Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., took aim at the newly released House GOP budget, saying it falls far short of what needs to be done to deal with the federal deficit.
92.text:
In an exclusive interview with ABC News on February 4, 2011, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky expressed his dissatisfaction with the House GOP budget proposal, stating that it falls short in addressing the federal deficit.

According to Paul, the plan put forward by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan of Wisconsin does not adequately tackle the issue at hand. He noted a disconnect among Republicans, stating that while they advocate for a balanced budget, they may not be ready to discuss the necessary spending cuts.

Released on Thursday, Ryan's proposal aims to cut non-security discretionary spending by $58 billion by the end of the fiscal year 2011, which concludes on September 30.

During the extensive interview conducted aboard the Capitol Subway, Paul declared himself a "true believer" and expressed his commitment to the principles of the Tea Party movement. He emphasized that his dedication to these values supersedes his affiliation with the Republican party. Additionally, Paul did not rule out the possibility of running for president in the future and suggested a potential reduction in U.S. forces in Afghanistan.

Paul has presented his own plan to slash spending by $500 billion in the current year. His proposal includes significant across-the-board cuts, such as an 83 percent reduction in funding for the Department of Education, a 6 percent reduction for the Department of Defense, and an elimination of all foreign aid. However, Paul views these cuts as merely a starting point.

Paul shared feedback he has received at tea party events, where attendees consistently demand more substantial action. He said they express their concerns, stating, "It's not enough. It's not enough. Where's the other trillion you need?"

While defending his position on ending all foreign aid, including the $3 billion given annually to Israel, Paul clarified that he remains supportive of the country. However, he stressed that it is not prudent to borrow money to provide assistance, even to friendly nations.

Addressing critics who argue against discontinuing aid to Israel, Paul maintained that the country possesses sufficient resources to sustain itself economically. He stated, "I think they're an important ally, but I also think that their per capita income is greater than probably three-fourths of the rest of the world. Should we be giving free money or welfare to a wealthy nation? I don't think so."

Paul also praised Israel's military capabilities, stating they outmatch those of their neighboring countries. "I think they're probably 10 years ahead of any neighboring country. I think that their defense is very significant and probably well in advance of any of their particular enemies," he remarked.

Regarding troop levels in Afghanistan, Paul expressed his belief that the decision falls within the purview of the president. However, he personally believes that a smaller presence would be sufficient.

Clearing any confusion about his political affiliations, Paul asserted that he prioritizes being a Tea Party activist over identifying as a Republican. He emphasized that certain issues in the nation's capital transcend party lines, stating, "There are always problems in our nation's capital that are more important than party affiliation, and I will always believe that." When questioned about the importance of party loyalty, Paul firmly responded, "If you ask me what's more important, tackling our nation's deficit, our nation's debt problems or being a Republican, I would say tackling the debt."
92.title: ABC News Exclusive: Rand Paul Criticizes Republican Approach to Deficit Reduction

93.description: Donald Trump said “hedge fund guys are getting away with murder” when he called for ending a lucrative tax advantage for investment managers, but his published tax plan would give them an even bigger break.
93.text:
President Donald Trump’s recent rhetoric on implementing stricter taxes for hedge funds may not align with his actual plan, raising concerns about the effectiveness of his proposed measures.

During his presidential campaign and even after taking office, Trump repeatedly criticized the hedge-fund industry, claiming that it exploits tax loopholes and benefits from preferential treatment. He vowed to close these loopholes and make hedge funds pay their fair share of taxes.

However, a closer analysis of Trump's tax plan reveals a different story. Rather than cracking down on hedge-fund tax practices, his proposed reforms primarily focus on lowering corporate tax rates and providing relief for high-income individuals. This discrepancy begs the question: is Trump's tough talk on hedge-fund taxes nothing more than political posturing?

While the proposed reforms might have positive impacts on the overall economy, critics argue that they do not address the specific issues surrounding hedge-fund taxation. The lack of specific measures targeting this industry raises doubts about Trump's commitment to tackling the concerns he previously expressed.

Hedge funds are known for utilizing complex strategies to minimize their tax obligations legally. Critics argue that these practices allow hedge-fund managers to pay lower effective tax rates compared to many middle-class Americans. This income inequality has fueled public anger and calls for reform.

The tension between Trump's tough rhetoric and his actual plan is further amplified by the presence of former hedge-fund managers within his administration. Critics argue that influential figures from the industry, such as Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, may influence policy decisions in favor of their former colleagues instead of implementing reforms.

As the President continues to push for his ambitious tax reforms, it remains to be seen whether he will truly address the concerns surrounding hedge-fund taxes. Trump's tough talk may have garnered attention, but its alignment with his actual plan is still questionable.

A comprehensive and fair tax system requires a diligent and genuine effort to close any loopholes that allow certain industries to disproportionately benefit. Only time will tell if the President's words will translate into meaningful action or if his tough talk on hedge-fund taxes is merely political rhetoric aimed at appeasing the public.
93.title: Trump's Tough Talk on Hedge-Fund Taxes Doesn't Match His Plan

94.description: Newt Gingrich may be big-government conservatism’s leading messenger, but his temperament and character distort the effect.
94.text:
Of all the major Republicans, the one who comes closest to my worldview is Newt Gingrich. Despite his erratically shifting views and odd phases, he continually returns to this core political refrain: He talks about using government in energetic but limited ways to increase growth, dynamism, and social mobility.

In a 2007 statement, Gingrich declared his political ideology, stating, "It's not a point of view libertarians would embrace, but I am more in the Alexander Hamilton-Teddy Roosevelt tradition of conservatism. I recognize that there are times when you need government to help spur private enterprise and economic development."

Gingrich highlights key instances in American history to support his viewpoint. He references how the government provided railroad land grants to encourage the widespread adoption of a modern transportation system. Similarly, the Homestead Act gave away land to those willing to live on and develop it. Gingrich further points out that public-private partnerships were employed to bring telephone service and electricity to all communities in the nation. These examples demonstrate how government involvement can serve public purposes without leading to excessive bureaucracy.

This consistent theme in Gingrich's career sets him apart, highlighted by his 1984 book, "Window of Opportunity." In the book, he vehemently criticizes the "laissez-faire" conservatism, which promotes the idea that the government should step back and let the market flourish. Gingrich argues that an opportunity society requires active government intervention to foster growth and provide equal opportunities.

Despite facing criticism and encountering tumultuous political phases, Gingrich's unwavering belief in the power of limited government intervention to drive growth and social progress remains a defining aspect of his philosophy.
94.title: The Gingrich Tragedy - The New York Times

95.description: Making appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2007, and for other purposes.
95.text:
The Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2007 (H.R. 5441) was a bill considered by the 109th Congress of the United States. In order for a bill to become law, it must be passed by both the House of Representatives and the Senate in the same form, and then signed by the President.

It is important to note that bill numbers restart every two years, so there may be other bills with the same number. The H.R. 5441 referenced here is specific to the 109th Congress.

The 109th Congress was in session from January 4, 2005, to December 9, 2006. Any legislation not passed by the end of a Congress is no longer valid.

To cite this information in academic work, the following MLA format is recommended:

GovTrack.us. (2023). H.R. 5441 — 109th Congress: Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2007. Retrieved from https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/109/hr5441
