114.text:
President Obama delivered an impassioned speech at Scranton High School in Scranton, Pennsylvania, advocating for the extension of tax cuts for middle-class Americans. The President stressed the importance of providing support to working families and strengthening the economy during these challenging times.

During his speech, President Obama highlighted the economic struggles faced by many Americans over the past decade, including job losses, stagnant wages, and rising costs of education and healthcare. He emphasized that the American Dream of hard work leading to success was slipping away for many people and called for renewed efforts to rebuild the economy.

President Obama outlined his American Jobs Act, a comprehensive jobs bill aimed at creating more employment opportunities and putting more money in the pockets of working families. The bill received bipartisan support and was backed by independent economists who projected it could create up to 2 million jobs and boost the economy by as much as 2 percent.

However, the President expressed disappointment in the Senate's refusal to debate the bill and the lack of support from Republicans. He called on Congress to reconsider and vote in favor of the American Jobs Act, specifically highlighting the need to extend tax cuts for middle-class families.

The President stressed the importance of extending the payroll tax cut, set to expire at the end of the year. He explained that failing to extend this tax cut would result in a $1,000 increase in taxes for the average middle-class family, which would also have a detrimental impact on the economy as it continues to recover from the recession.

President Obama urged Congress to prioritize the needs of working families over protecting tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires. He reiterated his belief in the collective responsibility Americans have in supporting and uplifting one another. Asking the wealthiest citizens to pay their fair share, he argued, would help create a more balanced and prosperous society.

The President called on the American people to voice their support for the extension of tax cuts to their senators, emphasizing the power of individual voices in shaping government actions. He urged Congress to put partisanship aside and work together to pass the American Jobs Act, emphasizing that America's best days lie ahead when its citizens unite in pursuit of progress.

President Obama concluded his speech by reminding the audience that America has always risen to the occasion during challenging times and expressed his confidence in the resilience and determination of the American people.

118.text:
Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton, laying out her economic vision, said Monday that government must do more to rein in excessive risk taking on Wall Street, push financial firms to focus on long-term growth over short-term gains and assure stock markets “work for everyday investors, not just high-frequency traders.” She also touched on the so-called sharing economy and its promise and pitfalls. Here is a transcript of her remarks, provided by Federal News Service (www.fednews.com).

Clinton emphasized the need to address the concerns of the American people who feel that the economy is stacked in favor of the wealthy. She discussed the importance of the middle class and the promise of a basic bargain, that if individuals work hard and do their part, they should be able to get ahead.

She criticized the Republican approach of cutting taxes for the wealthy and big corporations, arguing that it does not benefit hard-working Americans. Clinton pointed to the success of the Clinton and Obama administrations in improving the economy and raising incomes across the board.

Clinton outlined her agenda for economic growth and fairness, emphasizing the need for strong, fair, and long-term growth. She highlighted the importance of small businesses in creating jobs and proposed measures to support and empower entrepreneurs. Clinton also advocated for tax reform to ensure that wealthy individuals and corporations pay their fair share.

In addition, Clinton discussed the need for investment in infrastructure, renewable energy, and scientific and medical research. She emphasized the importance of early learning and high-quality education in ensuring future success and raising incomes.

Clinton addressed the issue of income inequality, calling for a better balance in the economy and advocating for the minimum wage increase and the implementation of President Obama’s rules on overtime. She also proposed profit-sharing as a way to benefit workers and companies.

Clinton highlighted the need for comprehensive immigration reform, arguing that bringing more people into the formal economy would stimulate economic growth. She also discussed the importance of fair trade agreements that create jobs and raise wages.

Clinton called for reforms in the financial industry, including stronger regulation and stricter penalties for misconduct. She emphasized the need to prioritize long-term growth over short-term gains and proposed measures to encourage companies to invest in their workers and communities.

Finally, Clinton stressed the importance of collaboration and cooperation in tackling economic challenges, urging policymakers, business leaders, and academics to work together to find solutions.

Overall, Clinton’s speech focused on her vision for a “growth and fairness economy” that raises incomes for hardworking Americans, encourages business growth and innovation, and addresses income inequality and other economic challenges.
118.title: Hillary Clinton Transcript: Building the ‘Growth and Fairness Economy’

119.description: Federal health officials needed the Peanut Corporation of America’s permission before announcing a recall of its products, which may have delayed contamination warnings.
119.text:
WASHINGTON - The Peanut Corporation of America, currently under investigation for potentially knowingly selling contaminated products, played a significant role in the recent product recall announced by the federal health officials. Surprisingly, the government was required to obtain the consent of the company before publicly disclosing the recall.

In accordance with existing regulations, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) was bound to seek approval from the company for the wording of the recall statement. This practice highlights the agency's reliance on cooperation from food manufacturers, even in cases where criminal activities are suspected.

The FDA's perceived leniency, in light of this incident, has drawn criticism from some members of the Democratic Party in Congress. They argue that the agency should be granted additional authority to prevent such occurrences in the future.

Responding to these concerns, President Obama pledged to conduct a thorough review of FDA operations. In an interview on the "Today" show, he expressed his disappointment, stating, "I think that the FDA has not been able to catch some of these things as quickly as I expect them to catch."
119.title: Peanut Product Recall Took Company Approval

120.description: Stephen Colbert takes on cable news pundits (and everyone else) in this political satire.
120.text:
Stephen Colbert, the brilliant political satirist, captivated audiences for nearly a decade with his renowned television series "The Colbert Report." Through his sharp wit and fearless persona, Colbert fearlessly took on cable news pundits and a wide range of public figures, becoming a voice of reason and laughter in a sea of political discourse.

"The Colbert Report" aired from 2005 to 2014 and quickly gained popularity for its unique and innovative format. Colbert portrayed a fictional conservative commentator, also named Stephen Colbert, parodying the style and mannerisms of real-life political pundits. Through this satirical lens, Colbert managed to cleverly dissect the absurdities and hypocrisies of American politics and media.

Colbert's wit and humor were integral to his approach. His sharp and quick-witted monologues tackled current events with biting satire, often exposing the flaws and contradictions within the news media itself. Additionally, Colbert invented catchphrases such as "truthiness" that became part of mainstream discourse, highlighting his ability to blend comedy and commentary seamlessly.

"The Colbert Report" successfully created a platform for Colbert to confront notable figures and politicians. The show featured a diverse array of guests, including renowned politicians, authors, and entertainers, all of whom found themselves drawn into Colbert's web of satire. Famous interviews, such as Colbert's playful grilling of former President Bill Clinton, showcased his ability to challenge and entertain simultaneously.

Beyond its comedic elements, "The Colbert Report" had a profound impact on American political culture. The show's popularity demonstrated the public's appetite for smart and incisive political satire, inspiring other satirical programs and personalities to follow suit. Colbert also used his platform to raise awareness of important political issues, encouraging viewers to be politically engaged and informed.

Colbert's portrayal of an egotistical right-wing media figure was particularly timely. It provided a satirical mirror to the prevalent personalities dominating cable news, unveiling the tactics and exaggerated opinions often utilized in political media. His relentless mockery of these antics served as a powerful reminder to audiences to question the sources of their news and the authenticity of those delivering it.

In conclusion, "The Colbert Report" showcased Stephen Colbert's talent in merging comedy and politics to form a satirical tour-de-force. Through his portrayal of a fictional conservative pundit, Colbert fearlessly took on cable news and public figures alike, exposing the flaws and contradictions within the political landscape. With his humor, intelligence, and unapologetic approach, Colbert left an indelible mark on both television and political discourse.
120.title: Stephen Colbert's "The Colbert Report" Mixes Comedy and Politics

121.description: Read a transcript of Clinton's remarks in Cleveland about the attacks at an Orlando nightclub.
121.text:
Speaking in Cleveland, Ohio, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton called for unity in the wake of the tragic shooting in Orlando. Here are key moments from that speech. (Video: Reuters/Associated Press)

Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic presidential candidate, addressed a crowd in Cleveland and pledged to take on "lone wolves" who might carry out terrorist attacks in the United States. She called for unity in the face of the recent massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando.

Clinton began her speech by expressing her gratitude to everyone in attendance and commending the work done at the Industrial Innovation Center. She specifically praised Team Wendy for their efforts to protect troops and first responders from traumatic brain injuries. The audience expressed their support for Clinton throughout her speech, chanting "We want Hillary!"

Acknowledging the tragic events in Orlando, Clinton emphasized that it was not a day for politics. She highlighted the nightmare that Americans woke up to and condemned the act of terrorism that took place in a place no one expected. Clinton stressed that the shooter was filled with hate and targeted LGBT Americans, representing an attack on the openness and diversity that defines the American way of life.

While the investigation into the shooter and his motives is ongoing, Clinton called for a united front against terrorism. She stated that the threat posed by radical jihadists is profound and must be defeated. Clinton reaffirmed her plan to defeat ISIS and other radical jihadist groups, emphasizing that the coalition effort in Syria and Iraq has made recent gains. She proposed ramping up the air campaign, providing support to friends fighting on the ground, and urging regional partners to do more.

Clinton also called for the hardening of defenses at home, providing better support to first responders, law enforcement, and intelligence officers. She stressed the need for improved intelligence and resources to prevent attacks before they happen. Clinton reiterated her stance on assault weapons, stating that if someone is on the FBI's watchlist, they should not be able to easily obtain a firearm.

In addition to taking action against jihadists, Clinton emphasized the importance of countering radicalization and preventing the recruitment efforts of ISIS and other terrorist networks. She called for better cooperation with Muslim American communities and worked towards building relationships based on trust. Clinton also highlighted the need to combat online propaganda by intercepting communication, tracking social media posts, and promoting credible voices.

Clinton ended her speech by emphasizing the strength of the American people when united and called for a sense of common purpose, just as Americans displayed after the 9/11 attacks. She expressed her confidence that Americans will overcome the threats of terrorism and other challenges when they come together.
121.title: ‘Americans need to stand together’: Hillary Clinton’s remarks following the Orlando shooting

122.description: U.S. Rep. H. Morgan Griffith is milking his opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency for every last drop. The R
122.text:
U.S. Rep. H. Morgan Griffith has been vocal about his opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and has made several claims criticizing the agency. One of his recent claims, made in a February newsletter to constituents, is that the EPA treats milk spills the same way they treat oil spills. However, a closer look at the facts reveals that Griffith's claim is misleading and exaggerated.

Griffith argues that a new ruling by the EPA forces dairy farmers to comply with the same regulations as oil and natural gas producers when dealing with milk spills. He suggests that this is an outrageous and unnecessary burden on dairy farmers. However, the claim is not entirely accurate.

A visit to the EPA's website reveals that milk has actually been regulated under the Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) program since 1973, when the Clean Water Act was passed by Congress. The law defines milk as an oil, as it contains a percentage of animal fats. Therefore, milk spills have been subject to regulations for the past 38 years and this is not a new ruling, as Griffith suggests.

Griffith's claim also fails to acknowledge that the SPCC rule applies only to farms storing more than 1,320 gallons of oil or milk. So smaller dairy farms storing a limited amount of milk would not be affected by these regulations.

In fact, the EPA made a rule change in 2009, which is set to go into effect soon, that actually exempts milk and dairy farms from the spill rules governing oil products. The change states that milk containers and associated piping and appurtenances would be exempt from SPCC requirements as long as they meet specific sanitary standards and adhere to pasteurization laws.

It is important to note that the change in regulations primarily applies to large-scale dairy farms that store petroleum products, such as gasoline or fuel oil, in significant quantities. It does not affect the majority of dairy farmers or the storage of milk itself.

Griffith's claim seems to have been influenced by an editorial in The Wall Street Journal, which also misinterpreted the EPA's rule change. However, as a congressman, Griffith has a responsibility to ensure the accuracy of his statements and should have verified the information before making such claims.

In conclusion, Morgan Griffith's statement that a "new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply" with strict spill regulations, similar to those imposed on oil and natural gas companies, is false. The regulations for milk spills have been in place for several decades and the recent rule change actually exempts milk from certain spill standards. It is important for public officials to provide accurate information to the public, particularly when discussing important environmental regulations.
122.title: Morgan Griffith Misrepresents EPA's Treatment of Milk Spills in Comparison to Oil Spills

123.description: We look into what exactly Donald Trump has said about getting rid of gun-free zones in schools.
123.text:
f the nine items that the Clinton campaign has highlighted as something "every voter in America needs to know about Donald Trump" is his plan to eliminate gun-free zones in schools on his first day in office. While Trump himself has not publicly discussed this proposal at length, it has drawn attention and raised concerns.

The Gun-Free School Zones Act, enacted in 1990, makes it illegal to carry or discharge a firearm in a school zone. However, states have the authority to decide whether to allow concealed carry at K-12 schools or colleges. Most states currently prohibit concealed carry. There is a debate among advocates on both sides of the gun-rights and gun-control spectrum as to whether the law preventing firearms on school grounds actually deters or motivates potential attackers.

Since the tragic shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, some states have introduced legislation to arm teachers and staff at K-12 schools. In response, at least 33 states introduced over 80 bills in 2013 alone, authorizing school districts to permit certain teachers and staff to carry concealed firearms. Additionally, more states have been considering laws that allow guns on college campuses.

While Trump has been vocal about his opposition to gun-free zones at military bases and has expressed his desire to repeal them, he has not spoken as openly about doing the same for schools. The only time he spoke about it publicly was at a rally in Vermont in January 2016, where he stated that he would eliminate gun-free zones in schools on his first day in office. However, he did not provide specific details about how this would be achieved or what the implications would be.

Trump's response to questions about his proposal during an interview with the Outdoor Channel also lacked specifics. He indicated that he would work with the states and potentially override them if necessary. However, it remains unclear if he would propose repealing the federal ban on guns in school zones or make it illegal for states to pass laws prohibiting concealed carry at schools.

In conclusion, while Trump has not provided many specifics regarding his proposal, it is evident that he intends to force states to allow guns in schools. Whether this would be achieved through a repeal of the federal ban or through other means is still unclear. However, Trump's intention to make this happen on his first day as president is clear.
123.title: Trump’s Proposal to Allow Guns in Schools Raises Questions

124.description: President Trump campaigned in the Pittsburgh area for Rick Saccone, the Republican candidate in the March 13, 2018, 18th Congressional District special election. The president talked about a wide range of issues including his new steel and aluminum tariffs, the plan to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, the Republican tax reform law, and tougher penalties for drug dealers.
124.text:
President Trump campaigned in Moon Township, Pennsylvania on Saturday, to rally support for Rick Saccone, the Republican candidate running in the special election for the 18th Congressional District set to take place on March 13, 2018.

During his speech, President Trump touched upon a variety of topics, addressing his administration's recent decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. He defended these measures, emphasizing their significance in protecting American industries and ensuring fair trade. The President also expressed his intention to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, a historic event that has garnered global attention and potential implications for international relations.

Moreover, President Trump praised the successful passing of the Republican tax reform law, highlighting its positive impact on businesses and the economy. He reiterated his commitment to reducing excessive regulations and creating a favorable environment for economic growth.

In his address, the President also focused on the issue of drug addiction, advocating for stricter penalties for drug dealers as part of the administration's efforts to combat the opioid epidemic that has ravaged the nation. President Trump stressed the importance of addressing this pressing crisis and ensuring that those responsible for perpetuating it face severe consequences.

Rick Saccone, the Republican candidate endorsed by President Trump, took the stage to express his gratitude for the President's support. Saccone pledged to work diligently to advance the President's agenda and represent the interests of the people of Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District.

As the March 13 special election draws near, the outcome will serve as a crucial indication of the political landscape in the lead-up to the 2018 midterm elections. The race between Saccone and his Democratic opponent, Conor Lamb, has attracted national attention and significant campaign spending. President Trump's visit to Pennsylvania underscores the importance of this election in maintaining a Republican majority in Congress, while Democrats aim to secure a victory that could potentially shift the balance of power.

125.description: Michigan Assembly Plant Wayne, Michigan 4:22 P.M. EST
125.text:
President Obama recently visited the Michigan Assembly Plant in Wayne, Michigan to deliver a speech on the resurgence of the American auto industry. In his address, the President expressed his admiration for the hard work and dedication of the workers at the plant and highlighted the progress made by the industry in recent years.

The President began his speech by acknowledging the leaders present at the event, including Secretary of Labor Tom Perez, Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan, Senator Gary Peters, Congresswoman Debbie Dingell, and Ford CEO Mark Fields. He also thanked Mia, who gave a spirited introduction before his speech.

President Obama took a moment to interact with the crowd, expressing his love for the Secret Service and jokingly responding to an audience member's declaration of love. He then praised the Michigan-made cars, particularly the new Mustangs, comparing them favorably to the cars he typically rides in as President.

The President proceeded to highlight the positive developments in the American auto industry. He emphasized the fact that 2014 was the strongest year for job growth since the 1990s and that the United States has had a 57-month streak of private sector job creation. He also mentioned that American manufacturing is experiencing its best stretch of job growth since the 1990s, with Michigan alone adding over 100,000 manufacturing jobs.

President Obama credited the steps taken early on to rescue and rebuild the economy for the current state of progress. He highlighted that the American auto industry, which had faced severe challenges, was now back on track. He mentioned that Ford, in particular, had not only survived but thrived, creating thousands of new jobs.

The President commended the partnership between labor and management in the auto industry, emphasizing that shared sacrifice and responsibility were key to its success. He noted that Ford had rejected the false choice of prioritizing shareholders over workers and had managed to benefit both parties. President Obama reaffirmed his belief that America is at its best when everyone is working together for the greater good.

The President then discussed the positive impact of the auto industry's recovery on the middle class. He stated that the industry's resurgence proved that any comeback is possible and that American manufacturing has a future. He acknowledged the challenges that both Detroit and the industry still face but expressed confidence in their ability to overcome those obstacles.

Before concluding the speech, President Obama shared the inspiring story of a veteran named Ramone, who found employment at Ford after struggling to secure a job upon returning from military service. The President used Ramone's story as an example of the American spirit of resilience and determination.

In his final remarks, President Obama reassured the audience that he would continue to support the revival of American industries and the middle class. He expressed his commitment to working alongside the hardworking men and women of the auto industry to ensure a prosperous future for America.

The President's visit to the Michigan Assembly Plant highlights the remarkable recovery of the American auto industry and serves as a testament to the hard work and dedication of its workers.
125.title: President Speaks on Resurgence of American Auto Industry at Michigan Assembly Plant

127.description: CBO and the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation have estimated the direct spending and revenue effects of H.R. 6079, the Repeal of Obamacare Act, as passed by the House of Representatives on July 11, 2012.
127.text:
CBO and the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) have estimated the direct spending and revenue effects of H.R. 6079, the Repeal of Obamacare Act, as passed by the House of Representatives on July 11, 2012. This estimate reflects the spending and revenue projections in CBO’s March 2012 baseline, adjusted to take into account the effects of the recent Supreme Court decision regarding the ACA.

The estimated budgetary effects of repealing the ACA by enacting H.R. 6079 are close to but not equivalent to, an estimate of the budgetary effects of the ACA with the signs reversed.
127.title: Letter to the Honorable John Boehner Providing an Estimate for H.R. 6079, the Repeal of Obamacare Act

128.description: Sen. Flake delivered the speech to the Senate on Wednesday.
128.text:
In a stirring speech delivered on the Senate floor, Senator Jeff Flake expressed his concerns about the erosion of truth in American democracy and the attacks on the free press. He emphasized that without truth and a commitment to shared facts, our democracy cannot survive.

Flake condemned the use of "alternative facts" by the Trump administration as a justification for falsehoods. He highlighted the relentless assault on the free press by the White House, referring to President Trump's labeling of the media as "the enemy of the people." Flake compared this rhetoric to that used by Josef Stalin, expressing his deep concern.

The senator argued that it is the duty of those in power to uphold the truth, not to undermine it. He praised the courage of journalists who risk their lives to report the truth, emphasizing that their work should not be dismissed as "fake news."

Flake raised concerns about the spread of untruths by politicians, pointing out the dangerous consequences of denying the reality of Russian interference in the U.S. elections. He criticized the lack of action on this matter and warned that ignoring or denying the truth leaves the country vulnerable to further attacks.

The senator expressed his disappointment with President Trump's intention to announce "corrupt and dishonest" media awards via Twitter. He called the spectacle disgraceful and stressed the need for 2018 to be the year when truth takes a stand against those who seek to weaken it.

Flake highlighted examples of foreign leaders using the term "fake news" to justify repression and undermine free speech. He warned that the authoritarian impulse to challenge free societies is resurfacing worldwide, and it is essential to confront it.

In conclusion, Flake emphasized that it is the press's responsibility to uncover the truth about those in power. He quoted President John F. Kennedy, who said, "For a nation that is afraid to let its people judge the truth and falsehood in an open market is a nation that is afraid of its people."

Flake called for an end to the attacks on truth and urged his colleagues to support the truth and defend democratic institutions. He closed his speech with a hymn, emphasizing that truth is eternal and will withstand the worst challenges.
128.title: Jeff Flake Criticizes Trump's Attacks on Truth and the Free Press

PolitiFact is providing an annotated transcript of the second presidential debate at Washington University. Throughout the night, they will be posting the transcript along with their annotations. Readers can follow their coverage on Medium and check back regularly to read their commentary.

The debate begins with the introduction of the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, and the Democratic nominee for president, Hillary Clinton. They both have two minutes to respond to the first question, which comes from a member of the town hall audience.

The question focuses on whether the candidates are modeling appropriate and positive behavior for today's youth. Secretary Clinton responds first, emphasizing the importance of teaching children to value respect and diversity. She talks about her positive and optimistic view for the country and her hope to bring the nation together.

Mr. Trump follows, agreeing with Clinton's statements and expressing his desire to make America great again. He criticizes current deals made by the government and highlights the need for strong borders and law enforcement. He also mentions his plans to improve conditions for African-American and Hispanic citizens.

The next question addresses the controversial tape that was leaked, in which Trump made derogatory comments about women. He is asked if he understands that his comments constitute sexual assault. Trump denies that he actually did what he said on the tape, referring to it as "locker room talk." He then shifts the focus to the issues of terrorism and violence in the world, stating his determination to defeat ISIS.

Clinton responds by stating her belief that Trump's comments on the tape accurately represent who he is. She criticizes his treatment of women throughout the campaign and mentions specific incidents where women were insulted or demeaned. She states that this behavior, along with his derogatory comments about other groups of people, raises questions about his fitness to be president.

The debate continues with discussions about various topics, including healthcare, emails, and the Affordable Care Act. Both candidates present their viewpoints and argue their positions. Trump criticizes the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, and promises to repeal and replace it with a better plan. Clinton defends the Affordable Care Act, acknowledging its flaws but emphasizing the benefits it has provided to millions of Americans.

The debate becomes heated, with Trump accusing Clinton of deleting thousands of emails and calling for a special prosecutor to investigate her actions. Clinton maintains her previous statements about her email scandal, denying any wrongdoing and insisting that no classified information was mishandled. She accuses Trump of making false claims and diverting attention from the real issues.

Ultimately, both candidates present their plans and arguments, with Clinton emphasizing her experience and desire to work for the American people and Trump promising to make America great again. The debate ends with both candidates addressing the audience's questions and making final remarks.

PolitiFact provides annotations throughout the transcript, fact-checking the candidates' statements and providing additional context and information. Their goal is to help readers understand the facts behind the candidates' claims and make informed decisions.

Renowned author Sue Grafton, best known for her beloved alphabet mystery series, sadly passed away on December 28, 2017, at the age of 77. Grafton began her impressive literary journey in 1982 with the publication of her first book, "‘A’ Is for Alibi," capturing readers' hearts and setting the stage for an unforgettable literary legacy.

Throughout her prolific career, Grafton intricately weaved suspense and intrigue into each installment of her series, guiding readers on thrilling adventures alongside her celebrated protagonist, private investigator Kinsey Millhone. With her talent for crafting captivating narratives, Grafton entranced fans and established herself as one of the most respected authors in the mystery genre.

Grafton's remarkable dedication to her craft is evident in the fact that she continued to write and publish her alphabet series up until her final book, "‘Y’ Is for Yesterday," released in August 2017. In a heartfelt statement, Grafton's daughter shared, "As far as we in the family are concerned, the alphabet now ends at Y." The news of Grafton's passing leaves her millions of readers mourning the loss of a beloved storyteller while reflecting on the indelible impact she has made on the literary world.

Her books, filled with complex characters, intricate plots, and a touch of wit, have garnered numerous accolades and captivated a global following. Sue Grafton's novels have frequently graced the prestigious New York Times bestseller list, establishing her as a literary force to be reckoned with.

Grafton's passing is not only a significant loss to the literary community but also to the countless fans who have eagerly awaited each new release, anxiously turning pages to devour another thrilling chapter in her alphabet series. While her final book, "‘Y’ Is for Yesterday," serves as a fitting conclusion to her celebrated series, it is undoubtedly bittersweet news for those who have come to cherish Kinsey Millhone's adventures.

Sue Grafton leaves behind a legacy of remarkable storytelling, leaving readers with a treasure trove of mysteries to enjoy for generations to come. Her contribution to the genre will be remembered fondly, and she will forever hold a special place in the hearts of readers worldwide.
130.title: Renowned Author Sue Grafton Passes Away, Concluding Iconic Alphabet Mystery Series

131.description: Gun control advocates often cite the statistic that 90 percent of Americans support expanding background checks for gun
131.text:
Conservative radio talk show host, Laura Ingraham, recently made a statement on Fox News Sunday, suggesting that the widely cited statistic claiming 90 percent of Americans support expanding background checks for gun purchases was false. However, fact-checkers have found her claim to be inaccurate.

A number of respected polls conducted in 2015 consistently reveal significant support for expanded background checks for gun purchases. For instance, a Quinnipiac University poll conducted in December 2015 found that 89 percent of respondents supported requiring background checks for people buying guns at gun shows or online. A CBS/New York Times poll from October 2015 showed that 92 percent of respondents favored a federal law requiring background checks on all potential gun buyers. Similarly, a Gallup poll conducted in the same month found that 86 percent of respondents favored a law mandating universal background checks for all gun purchases.

These polls show a strong trend of support for background checks, with results consistently hovering around the 90 percent mark. Pew Research Center's 2015 survey further demonstrated that support for background checks is not limited to specific partisan or demographic groups, and it even extends to a majority of households that own guns.

Despite Ingraham's claim, there is no definitive debunking of the statistic. Some gun rights advocates have contested the survey questions used in these polls, arguing that they refer to the general idea of background checks rather than specific legislation. This distinction may explain why support for general gun control measures does not necessarily translate into support for expanding gun control policies.

While people overwhelmingly favor specific gun control policies, such as universal background checks and preventing suspected terrorists from purchasing guns, the support becomes less robust when it comes to actually expanding gun control measures. A CBS/New York Times poll found that 46 percent of Americans believe gun sales laws should either remain the same or be made less strict, while only 51 percent felt the laws should be more strict.

In conclusion, Ingraham's claim that the 90 percent statistic supporting background checks has been debunked is false. Multiple respected polls from 2015 consistently demonstrate strong support for expanded background checks among Americans. While there may be some dispute over the interpretation of these findings and the level of support for specific legislation, there has been no definitive debunking of the overall statistic.
131.title: Laura Ingraham's Claim About Gun Background Check Support Debunked
